description: Found it on Yelp and felt inclined to write this review. It was by far, the best Italian food my wife and I have ever eaten.  Better than the food was the incredible service. Would no doubt, definitely go back on our next trip to San Francisco.
author: Sam E.

description: Came here for dinner, had the fettuccine puttanesca. The pasta was very good. It was fresh-made, and the texture was thus really magnificent. The sauce was also really good. A bit on the saltier side. Fiance had the ravioli di giorno. It was sweet and had a nice glaze, that almost had a bit of crisp to it. Atmosphere was intimate and lovely, however I can think of a couple of San Diego Italian joints that probably have this beat in terms of value and flavor.
author: Jenn C.

description: This is a neighborhood gem. Milano has great service and great Italian food. The ravioli are excellent and every appetizer I've tried has been flavorful and good. It is a small place so definitely make a reservation but it is still good for groups and a nice intimate date spot. Not too noisy and pretty good wine selection.
author: Tracey K.

description:
We started off with the Crostini ai Funghi and Grilled Calamari with Cannellini Beans. The buttery gorgonzola was the perfect complement to the mushrooms (which were loaded on...not stingy at all). The calamari was fresh and flavorful as well, although pretty pricey for the portion. My friend and I shared the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa and let me just say that we were still talking about it the next morning. It's well worth the richness and besides, you can take a leisurely post-dinner stroll. Maybe not leisurely given the hills...

Service was wonderful - Our waitress was bubbly and sweet and the owner made us feel welcome as well. The only thing I did not like was the bread...too dry for my taste.
author: Lauretta L.

description:
On Friday I went to Ristorante Milano for my boyfriend's birthday. I saw the reviews on yelp and it seemed a nice place to eat! We walk in and I think it was the owner who greeted us. We were seated by the door and the seating seemed very simple but cute. The people around us kept looking at us very weird, I'm guessing it was because we seem very young and the restaurant seems very classy and expensive. Anyway, We ordered an appetizer which was a mozzerrella something, and it was nothing we thought it would be, (my boyfriend that eats anything didn't even like it). We ordered lasagna and it was really good!! Also, since we don't drink wine all we had to drink was WATER. No sodas or anything. The owner kept walking around greeting everyone; asking how their food was but he never came to our table! He would ask the people right next to us but just skip us! He made us feel very uncomfortable and we honestly just wanted to cancel our order and leave. 
The only good thing was the lasagna and the gelato we got.

Probably won't be coming back here.
author: Mayra A.

description:
It was my best friend's dad's birthday.  We went out to celebrate.  The website seemed intriguing, freshly made focaccia and homemade pasta.  NUM!  Right? 

We went on a Wednesday.  Half price wine under $60.  Hell yeah!  We love our wine, and drink more than a bottle per couple, so this is a great deal. 

My friends had already ordered a white when we got there, and being more red drinkers, we decided to order a second.  We picked a wine based on a recommendation of our sweet waitress.  She brought it out, and didn't pay any attention whether it was acceptable.  Our "taster" was a little distracted by the menu, I fear.  Nevertheless, she went ahead and just started pouring it.  Meh, okay, thats fine.  

I tried it, and it had that indicative musty nose that it was on the brink of corked.  I'm super sensitive to it, and I decided not to say anything.  Until my friend looked across the table from me.  She didn't need to say anything, lol, and I nodded.  "Yep, its corked."  Once you smell it, there is no enjoyment in drinking it, really.  

So we said something to our waitress.  She smelled it, and actually tasted it.  She agreed with us.  She had another waiter do the same, and he too said, yep its on the brink,  Its not totally corked, but he could smell it.

The owner was a dick.  He basically was like thats how its supposed to taste and if we dont like it he will let us choose another wine.  Um, excuse me?!  Wine is supposed to taste corked?  Even my friends non-red wine loving mother could smell it.  We wine taste quite frequently, more often than I will reveal here.  We know our wine.  We know quality wine.  We typically drink French or Napa or Sonoma.  I was deeply offended as was my friend.

Besides that event, the salad was fantastic.  My butternut squash ravioli was....OMG...so sinfully good.  The gelato... meh...Ive had better.  The food was good and our waitress was extremely apologetic and fantastic, but I truly feel that I can't rate any higher because of the poor service we received from the owner.  It just left a sour taste in my mouth to have the owner be so disagreeable.  I'm sorry, I realize the economy is hurting right now.  I just can't imagine how its financially responsible to engage in poor customer service in a city where you have SO MANY choices.

P.S.  it was so freaking loud in there, that my friends dad couldn't even hear the dinner specials, and I too struggled to hear what people were saying.  Its a really bad layout.  If you want to listen to that crazy party the table next to you went to, this is a great place.
author: Jenna K.

description:
Decor - 3 stars (super busy and wait is between 30-60 minutes for a table for 4)

Food - 3 to 4 stars (my dish - the special pasta - was excellent, but my husband didn't really like his; friends thought theirs was good, but nothing to shout about)

Service - 3 to 4 stars (it was a little slow to order and get our food, but our glasses where filled quite quickly)

Price - 3 stars ($13 for the special scallops pasta - great pricing, but $16 for the veal parm??? wasn't that great)
author: Lisa L.

description: We had their risotto and pasta. It was very well done. Really like the atmosphere - small and cozy. Very good service too!
author: Catherine T.

description:
Why can't you give 3.5 stars?

Ristorante Milano is a nice, quaint spot that was great for a chill Friday night. I ordered the tuna carpaccio, which was really fresh and tastey. Our server was incredibly sweet, and I love the Italian accents you hear from everyone in the restaurant. :)
author: Amanda V.

description:
Best. Italian. Dinner. Ever. (Not located in actual Italy that is). 

The service was attentive but unobstrusive, the waiter was perfectly knowledgable about the menu and wine pairings. 

The food itself managed to both hit the authentic Italian notes perfectly while leaving room for a little innovation as in the beet ravioli. 

Dessert of Tiramisu and baked pear were a wonderful finish. 

I don't give 5 stars easily but Ristorante Milano earned it.
author: lach l.

description: Seriously one of the best Italian restaurants I've been to with such a reasonable price! Everything tastes fresh and well prepared. I recommend burrata, bruschetta, or arugula salad for an appetizer. And any and all entrées! The seafood pasta was killer if anyone is looking for a variety in their pasta. Lastly, as for the dessert, the chocolate cake was rich yet light, and the poached pear was had a very light sweet taste to top off a wonderful dinner.
author: Mako U.

description:
The place is a really good date spot.  The staff is extremely friendly and accommodating.  My friend and I came here without a reservation because we were craving Italian and this was the best rated place in the area.  

We ordered the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa and Fettucine alla Ghiotta.  Both were amazing.  For wine, we got the Chianti and Zinfandel -- don't remember which Zinfandel, but it was a bit spicy. 

Overall, a great experience.  It's quiet enough to actually carry on a conversation and the tables weren't so close to each other that you felt like you were intruding on your neighbors' meals.
author: S R.

description:
I really wanted to like you...

i met this wonderful guy, I really fall for him right away, then he asked me out right away. 
He took me here 6 years ago....it was our first date.
I was 19 but they still served my wine...OPPS!!!
also they served me burnt Lamb......
Left here unhappy and unsatisfied, but I was in love with this guy still GOOD TIME


2011, 3/6 is our 2yr wedding anniversary, even tho our first day wasn't perfect, but he was perfect for me :)

I wanted to give Milano another chance--to impress me again and bring back the first date feeling. and maybe I was too immature to know what good food was.

6:30 reservation for two, special comment on Opentable (this is our anniversary)
Walked in 6:30--about 5 out of 13-ish tables were full
asked us if we wanted side quiet table or upper to-see-all table. we chose by the window by ourselves table. 

Manu is 3-4 pages little notebook thing, only two pages wine--i guess CHARMING is exactly what it is. so small 

we ordered:
Carpaccio--is it frozen? or you cut them and put back to the freezer? it was little ice-y, little taste-less
Lamb-burnt a corner again --flash back!!!
Lasagna--home made egg noodles--very yummy
Italian white wine--aight~~

conclusion--not impressed, I am sorry with all high review. Cheaper eat. with wine the total came out $105, very good. but I guess all i have left is the great feeling about my husband not the place where we had our first date.

Will I go back---probly not.
author: Sisi W.

description:
If you're looking for some wonderfully authentic Italian food away from North Beach, this is your place. The food is rich, artfully prepared, and is served quick. The wine list is phenomenal. The gnocchi was the best I have ever had.

The only downside to this restaurant is that it's very small, so the tables are pushed close together, and the noise level is a little high.

It's great for a date, or even just to dine alone, if you don't mind pricey food,
author: Eliot J.

description:
Amazing authentic Italian food in lower Russian Hill. 

Food is absolutely great!  You won't find fancy or innovative dishes, but you get an amazing pasta that tastes like it does in Florence, Milan or Rome.

Decor is probably not to Hipster or Yupster or whatever 20 somethings call themselves, but the food is solid.

Parking flat out sucks.  Pay the $10 at the paint store on Polk and Pacific.

Caio.
author: Frank M.

description:
All of the homemade pastas are outstanding! Top recommendations: 
Angel hair pasta with the standard pomodoro sauce, but ask them to make it spicy. 
Fettuccine with pink sauce (combo meat + cream sauce) 
Also, if you happen to be there on the weekend, be sure to get the lasagna. It's a weekend-only special. 

These are not the typical flavor-bomb Italian dishes that you would find at Olive Garden or some of the other touristy places in North Beach. They are simple, fresh, and vibrant flavored dishes that you are more likely to find in Italy.
author: Amanda B.

description:
My girlfriend found this place in their neighborhood and it is a great find! The service was exceptional, very friendly and offered up suggestions for dinner. Wine list is great and offers something for everyone. 
The waitstaff (Andy) was very attentive and friendly, plus he let me practice my Italian. 
On top of all the positive experience there, the food was above expectations and delivered on every flavor. 
What a great neighborhood find!
author: Lisa B.

description:
Great service, great food. I went here with a friend and while we downed a bottle of wine we had the lasagne and one of the specials that night, shrimp with risotto and asparagus. Delicious! This place gets packed, so if you don't want to wait you will definitely need to make a reservation. For dessert, don't miss the chocolate and/or hazelnut gelato. 

Why 4 stars instead of 5? Because I can't stand it when a waiter comes up to you and tells you that another party is waiting for your table. That drives me nuts. I don't know how any restaurant thinks it's OK to rush their patrons. I will go there again for the terrific food but I won't be happy if I am asked to rush again.
author: Lori M.

description:
The quick summary? Quantity over quality...by a lot. Is it a surprise that a lot of people rate this place highly? Evidently people like lots of food.

Seated on time, the ambiance was fine. Thinking back to the early 1980s when this place was Gideo's I fondly recall many good meals here. Nobody here had even heard of Gideo's so I didn't bring it up again.

We were seated on the balcony in the rear. I had a great view of the back of a wine rack and the lovely aroma of the restrooms wafting over my dinner. Mmmmm. They really might consider doing something about this. But...on to the food and wine.

I asked the waitress, having little familiarity with most of the wine on the list, for something round and earthy. She pointed out a few she liked and suggested a Chianti Classico as her favorite. Putting ourselves in her experienced hands we went with it. Mistake. Super fruity with a giant spiky fruit taste, there was no earthiness, no roundness, no subtlety. Just shrieking, underage whine. We never got past a glass each. But the food would be better, right?

I ordered my salad...beets with grapefruit and a sprinkling of sheep cheese. The portion came out and was large enough to feed a small nation. It was obviously prepared earlier and refrigerated as it was ice cold. I ate about fifteen percent of it and couldn't consider another bite. The entree would be better I figured. It came in a while. Grigliata Mista, "Grilled combination of sausage, chicken breast and lamb". A big plate with, you may have guessed it, more beets. The beef was inedible. Bone and fat. The chicken was a think cutlet in some sort of gravy and the lamb was another thin cut full of spice. I had none of the beef, three bites of the lamb and two of the chicken and done.

The meal was a disaster on all fronts. I just don't get it. So much potential to do something good and they squander it on serving large portions of sub-par stuff. The design of the place is nice. Location...out of the way but not too far is good. An additional star off because of the missed potential. Too bad. I wonder what Gideo is up to these days.
author: Gary C.

description: We happened upon this place and fell in love!  Amazing staff, amazing food and fantastic environment.  We will be back!
author: Eve W.

description:
My second time here and this place still amazes me.  We booked a reservation on Thursday for NYE and they still had tables for dinner! 

Adorable decor, quick-ish service, and rich dishes.

Pros:
- Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa, Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa, Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa.  Rich, creamy, mushroomy delight.  The pasta is the perfect texture: chewy, delish.
- We split the pasta meal and they separated it into two plates for us to share!
- Tiramisu = not too sweet, light and delish.

Cons:
- Portions are smaller then I remember (granted calamari is seasonal so these are probably smaller)
-  Grilled calamari could be more flavorful
- Tables on the raised level are so close together
- I've been turned away at dinner time for not having reservations.  Make a reservation!
author: Traveling Tasters I.

description:
WARNING!!!!!! There is no way to get to this restaurant except UP.  That is, unless you are already up on Russian Hill.  We tried walking and uh, well, half of our party petered out and took a cab.  Its a great location and you have to make an effort to get there.
As for the restaurant itself, beautiful wood decor.  Lasagna Special was outstanding as was the butternut squash ravioli.  The staff was attentive, knowledgeable, and made great wine recommendations.
We did not stay for dessert but I saw a few go by and the recipients seemed pleased.  I would suggest eating here.
author: Diana M.

description: Great little place. Very glad we made reservations, could have a long wait. Lots of Italian spoken amongst the employees, made it feel very authentic. Serving sizes were good portions. Great wines. Tables pretty close together but it wasn't uncomfortable at all. Will go again when we trip back to San Fran.
author: Tara S.

description:
Ristorante Milano is a small gem of a place just off of Hyde Street.  Get on you climbing gear to reach it, as it's on a steep hill.  Service is good and attentive and the portions are amply sized.  So bring an appetite.  

I started with bruschetta that came with sauteed mushrooms and gorgonzola cheese.  This was nice enough, although the taste of the mushrooms seemed pallid.  I was left wondering whether the mushrooms were fresh or came from a can.

Fettucine with milanese meat sauce was al dente and a throwback to old style Italian.  The meat in the sauce was very finely minced and the sauce was very, very sweet.  Could sugar have been added to the sauce?

Finally chicken saltimbocca was a disappointment to me.   The cheese and proscuitto were there and yet in combination with the chicken it was bland.  And the sauce that should have had some taste of marsala was thin and without any taste of wine.
author: David D.

description:
I was not prepared to be so amazed by this place!

We called and made a reservation, showed up, and OOPS... no reservation under that name. Uhhh what?? We were so sad (we had already picked out a wine under $60 for half price) that we would have to find somewhere else. But they were really apologetic for having lost our reservation, and promised to give us the next table, so we stayed and waited... and I'm glad we did!

First of all, the wine was fantastic. We got the Valpolicella (ripasso style) and were really blown away. The waiter said it was a new addition to their wine list, and I hope they keep it!

The appetizer combo was the perfect dish to try a little of everything. I love marinated mushrooms... so that won me over. But if you only get one appetizer, get the eggplant! YUM

We got the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa, which is so earthy and rich. The mushroom flavor was so intense, we fought over it like crazed hobbits.

We got another simple pasta dish (can't recall the name). It was very tasty  (but couldn't live up to the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa). Then we had tiramisu for dessert. My mouth is watering just remembering it. The perfect end to a perfect meal. WE WILL BE BACK!!
author: Melissa H.

description:
This is a cute little neighborhood place.  The staff is nice and attentive.  The noise level is a bit high, so come here if you really don't want to hear your date talk.  I found I kept leaning into the bread basket to hear my bf speak....I had the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa and this is really really yummy and flavorful.  This dish alone is 5 stars, however I have to review the overall experience and well, it's a solid 3.  

A little surprised that dinner for 2 glasses of wine; 1 starter; 2 entrees; 1 dessert and 2 coffees came out to $100.  I just find it a bit much to pay for a mid-week dinner, but we wanted to try something new.  I would go back, but probably not for awhile.  There are too many great places to eat in this city that are better and less expensive.
author: Mao K.

description: I love their gnocchi and tiramisu!  Every time we've been here, we never leave disappointed.  The setting is intimate.  An absolute gem!
author: Lourdes M.

description:
I guess I can fathom the raves if you think of this as a neighborhood place, but it's not a destination and I would not travel far for an evening at Milano.

Yes, the pasta is homemade, delicious, and the portions are sizeable.  The dishes themselves are a bit homely--oversauced for the most part, strewn with a little too much musky, dark, limp, julienned basil.  But they go down easily and if that were all we had to talk about, I'd be up at around 4 stars for Milano.

But our experiences with other items are less successful.  For example, the complimentary focaccia and olive oil were both largely flavorless.

The bruschetta antipasto with heirloom tomatoes was billed as coming with gorgonzola but arrived with thick, largely flavorless discs of mozzarella, and the otherwise tasty chopped heirlooms were drowned in not very fruity olive oil and way, way too much garlic.  I would not order it again.

The proprieter is charming, and he graciously seated us quickly at a rear table in the loft area which quickly got very stuffy.

Our server, though, was far less charming.  She seemed a bit sour and there were long waits for water, then bread, then the appetizer.  And through all of this I waited nearly 30 minutes for a glass of wine, but when the error was finally detected it was comped.

My lasagna special featured delicate homemade pasta in at least 9 or 10 layers, with a tasty bechamel lurking between the layers, and a generous, maybe even slightly too generous layer of beef and veal meat sauce which was sweet and tasty.

My companion's fettuccini with Milanese meat sauce--the same sauce on the lasagna--was tasty, but way oversauced and the fettucine is not as delicate or perfectly elastic as we have had at, say, Pasta Moon in Half Moon Bay.

I liked the place and I might wander in if i the neighboorhood but given the waiting lines we saw on our exit, I doubt this is feasible, and if I have to go to the trouble for reservations, I'll likely opt for someplace a little more special than Milano.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Yummy!  Cute little Italian place that offers a variety of interesting dishes!  I went with two other people and we split all the food.
Here's what we had:
Butternut squash ravioli - yummy!! And they gave us 7-10 pieces instead of the usual 3-4.
Seared beef appetizer - interesting and delicious!  Thinly sliced beef seared with greens in the middle (plus vinaigrette, I think). 
Gnocchi with cheddar and gorgonzola - the yummiest mac n cheese I've ever had - the gorgonzola wasn't overpowering, and I really appreciated that.
Marinated veal with potatoes - good!  The veal was tender and the seasoned potatoes were great!
Tiramisu - pretty standard, not too strong on the booze.
Marinated poached pear + pear sorbet - sooooooo yummy!  This was my favorite by far.  The sweet pear just melts in your mouth and the sorbet is a nice compliment!

The location is a little off the beaten path, but well worth it!  I will go back again if I am in the area.  Seems to be better for smaller parties, but looks like they could accommodate if given enough warning.  Service was friendly and my iced tea and water were full most of the time.  Most dishes were in the teens to twenty dollar range, so if you add a drink and dessert you're probably looking at about $30-$40/person.
author: siutou s.

description:
Ristorante Milano is a good neighborhood Italian joint. Everything about it is small except for the potions (see the bathroom!). 

The seasonal beet salad was amazing and my favorite thing of the night if you can believe. It was a good helping of beets and some green beans in a light sauce. I also had a special for my entree which I enjoyed, the Scaloppine di Vitello (Veal). It comes with a prosciutto layer on top which was so good and some steamed veggies on the side. 

We had an annoying mix up with our reservations which left me now with minus one star. I had made them a week before, showed up with my in-laws from out of town, and they had no idea of our reservation. The man was very nice and took our phone number and said he would call when it opened up so we grabbed a glass of wine up the street. We got lucky they could seat us there! 

Luckily they squeezed us in, but we still had to wait about 35 minutes. Not sure what happened.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Delicious food, cozy atmosphere, and the servers are so attentive - they show you that they really do put their all into creating a nice experience.

I have eaten here once before and last night decided to take a try at calling to see if they did orders for pick up.  They sure do!  And the food was fantastic.  

Tried the linguine with shellfish in a white wine sauce.  This dish had a nice spiciness to it that I wasn't expecting.  I would definitely have this again.  We also ordered the Saltimbocca di Pollo and Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa which were both enjoyed.  I am so glad to know that this is an option!  The food was ready within 20 minutes and was hot and perfectly prepared for when we got this home to eat.
author: Janelle C.

description:
I didn't really have a great experience. I met up with a fabulous friend from out of town and really wanted to show her a great local restaurant.

The wait staff was slow even though the restaurant was not very full. My pasta dish was very bland and the clams/mussels were sandy. I tried this place about 4 years ago since it's in my neighborhood and did not have a good experience (burnt meat, bland food). I wanted to give it another try and now I know I won't be back.
author: Tien H.

description: My girlfriend and I visited San Francisco in June for our 4 year anniversary and after a long search of nice restaurants to go to dinner that offered vegetarian options, we decided on ristorante Milano. Being from the east coast, my girlfriend knows real Italian food and this is definitely real Italian food. I wish I remembered our servers name because he was awesome. He accommodated our vegetarian needs and everything was done in a timely manner. The service over all was incredible, and the atmosphere was so cool. When we made our reservation a week or two in advance we asked for a table near the window and when we got there, they already had it set up for us. We dressed up because it was our anniversary but the other people there were dressed roughly business casual, so it's flexible. Overall I have no complaints about this place. Definitely a nice restaurant to go to for a nice dinner. And their desserts are impeccable!
author: Madeline P.

description:
Tiny, but the food is good.

Tip: Bring someone that speaks Italian (or exercise your own ability) to get some speedy(er) service.
author: Wes T.

description:
Our sole criticism of this restaurant is that the tables are too close together. As usual, I deducted one star because we could easily overhear other patrons and they could overhear us.

"Wait a minute!" you say, "you rated it five stars." Yes, I know. Six stars for the food less one for the crowding is five stars.

We enjoyed an appetizer, entrees, desserts and a bottle of wine. All were very good to excellent. My housemade linguine with crimini mushrooms in a cream sauce was superb -- by far the best pasta I have ever experienced in a restaurant. This was the first time in my life that I have paid well over one hundred dollars for dinner for two without feeling that I might have eaten just as well someplace else for half the price.

Money well spent.
author: Lana G.

description: A hole in the wall with the most amazing homemade pasta. We were seated right away for our 7:00 reservation. The bread arrived right away, but it was cold and I was not a fan. Between our group of four, we had the Lasagna, Gnocchi con Salsa Aurora, Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa, and a seafood dish over a bed of polenta. Everything was cooked to perfection and I could not have asked for a better meal. Sadly, we were all so full from the entrees that we didn't have room to try to desserts. Next time!
author: Peggy L.

description: My husband and I had our first date here almost 18 years ago!  We've probably been there over a dozen times over the years and I cannot think of a time that the food and service were not top notch. We went again last night for our 16th wedding anniversary and the food was excellent!!! I love their homemade lasagne (it's only served Fri-Sun) and tiramisu!  But really whatever you order, it's going to be fabulous.  I love the atmosphere which is ideal for small parties 2-6 people and the noise level is very reasonable.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Cameron H.

description:
I recently dined here for new years eve and I was pleasantly surprised by how delicious it was. It was very busy and the waiters were very nice. I really liked the lasagna, it was delicious! Desert was good too. The pear was so good!
-1 star because I had a reservation at 10 PM and it got seated at around 10:30.
author: Christian L.

description: Go here. I am an Italian food snob and the food was quite good. Small place that is usually packed. Authentic roman food. Awesome
author: Christian D.

description: Excellent and tasty - the pasta was fresh, the garlic and tomato balance was perfect. We also took their wine pairing recommendation which was spot on. I recommend the tiramisu for dessert.
author: Christina F.

description: I havnt been here in 3 years but from what i remember the gnnochi is amazing!!!! It really was the star of the meal, and all my family (11 of us total) who I went with agreed. I am waiting to go back again. However, the appitisers and soup were just so so. I didn't really enjoy them and almost all of us agreed that each dish felt like it was missing something. The soup didnt have enough salt and was bland. The mushroom brushetta just had too many mushrooms on them and nothing else, it was a bit odd. Overall the gnnochi and other main dishes (pastas) are the most amaizng part of this restaurant and I am gonna go back just for them!
author: Toral S.

description:
Seriously, can we get half stars up on Yelp?

This is a cute little place in nob hill.  The place was packed - good thing we made reservations.  Fun spot for a double date + a bottle of wine.

Antipasto Misto- mix of their appetizers.. I really liked whatever it was that seemed like a zucchini quiche.  Mushrooms and peppers were also good.  When this comes out everyone definitely goes, "ooOoOoh....."
Saltimbocca di Pollo - YUM! Great presentation and was delicious. Probably could have finished the whole thing.. which means a lot!
Veal Ravioli - didn't particularly love how the veal tasted, would pass on this.
Gnocchi - everyone says this is AMAZING.  I think I'm just not a huge fan of gnocchi.. it was chewy and seemed to taste good?
author: Melody T.

description:
This was our first time here and there was 4 of us in our party. It was a Tuesday night and we were going to the Counting Crows concert. I wanted something within walking distance (7 blocks) of the Masonic Auditorium because I didn't want to think about driving and parking close to concert time. (we found street parking about 5 blocks away) After looking on-line at restaurants in the neighborhood, I decided that we should try this place. Most of the other reviews were generally favorable with very few poor reviews. Besides they took reservations and being on a schedule I couldn't take the chance of waiting to be seated. Turns out we probably didn't need the reservation, as we arrived shortly after the restaurant opened. Still it gave us piece of mind that we could have dinner before the show. 

Suffice it to say that the positive reviews were spot on! The food and service was excellent and I can see why it might be a good idea to make a reservation on a busier night. Given the opportunity, I would definitely come back and recommend it to anybody that loves Italian food at a reasonable price. After 2 appetizers, 4 glasses of wine, 4 pasta dishes, 2 desserts and a very generous tip; we got out of there for less than $50 a head. Truly a bargain and a great value for the neighborhood!
author: John B.

description:
Heavenly!!!  A group of us went here before a concert and had an amazing time.  Aldo the owner is very friendly and checked on us often making sure we were enjoying everything.  Our waitress was upbeat and friendly.

I had the vegan asparagus and zucchini soup and it was delicious.  Light and tasty.  The big hits on the table were the gnocchi without the tomato sauce, lasagna and lamp chops.  Just a heads up, the lasagna is only served on Friday and Saturday nights.  All of their pasta is homemade

For dessert I had the espresso shaved ice with whip cream on top and it was incredible and again, not heavy.

Definitely recommend this place and might be my new favorite Italian restaurant in SF!
author: Amanda K.

description: This is our go-to Italian restaurant in the neighborhood. We have eaten there countless times and we can't say enough good things about the place. If you are looking for cutting edge food, this is not the place for you. On the other hand if you want honest, traditional, well-made Italian food, Milano can't be beat. The service is wonderfully friendly and attentive without being intrusive. I have never felt rushed while dinning there. All of the people working there seem to like each other and to like working at Milano. The owner is there most nights and inspects many dishes before they leave the kitchen. The wine list is well thought out and the wine prices are reasonable. I especially like the fact that the noise level is low allowing normal conversation. One other good thing, the customers who dine there represent a wide range of ages.
author: Lee D.

description: I adore this little place. Go there often, it's just a few blocks from my apartment. Delicious, fresh Italian - sans  trite checked tablecloths and fake-accented wait staff. The staff can always recommend something, and I've learned to trust the chef and try the specials. I've never been disappointed.
author: Katrina K.

description:
I took my family here for dinner on Saturday. It's a cozy place (about 12-15 small tables which seat 2-4 each placed very close to each other); the ambiance is nice and subdued (but with enough noise/chatter so it doesn't feel like the whole restaurant would eavesdrop on your conversation), which can make this a nice date place to more intimate gathering of friends.

Food: not bad. I thought the gnocchi was excellent, but other than that, can't say I was too impressed with the food. The portions were European-sized - meaning don't expect to feel full off an entree by itself. =)

We ended up ordering the following:
Antipasto mista (basically appetizer sampler)
Grilled polenta with fresh mozarella and grilled red peppers
Gnocchi with gorgonzola and cream sauce
Lasagna
Seafood linguine
Veal saltimboca
Pasta with mushrooms and wine sauce
Tiramisu

Service: excellent, as should be expected with this type of restaurant.

Parking: painful.

Would I return? Probably not... I think there are many other Italian restaurants out there to try.
author: Steve L.

description:
Ristorante Milano is an excellent choice for quality Italian food and also, a lovely atmosphere. Read: great date place. I have been here many, many times over the years (used to live blocks away) and have never left unsatisfied or disappointed. 

There is one server in particular, an older Italian gent, and he is just so delightful: A beautiful untouched accent and knows how to sell the "evening specials" like no other. He really makes you feel like you're somewhere deep in Italy and not on Pacific Ave. blocks from Chinatown!

I don't think there's anything disappointing on the menu. From healthy protein choices to divine pasta dishes, go and enjoy.
author: Meredith R.

description: First time at this quaint, amazing restaurant.   The server was warm and inviting. The food  tasty. And the ambience romantic with candles and fresh roses. We started with a delicious tuna carpaccio. It was flavorful and satisfying. They serve you homemade focaccia bread with olive oil and balsamic vinegar. I highly recommended the linguini del mar. A tasty dish rich in mussels, clams, shrimp and scallops. My new fave place for Italian in San Francisco!
author: Angela A.

description: The food was fantastic and service was perfect as well.  I will say that the restaurant is rather small so be prepared for an intimate setting.  It didn't bother me at all but you need to be prepared that you will be dining very close to the table next to you.  My only complaint is that the markup on the wine was a bit higher than normal in my opinion but other than that, everything was great.  I'll be back again for sure.
author: Shane T.

description: This is a neighborhood place and seemed to cater to locals (we are from out-of-town). My husband had the Tonnarelli which he said was gummy and the sausage was very hard to find in the cream sauce.   Our son had Fettuccini Milanese, which he said was good but the pasta had a combination of both flour and spinach noodles.  There was no mention of this on the menu and our son cannot eat spinach, so half the dish was wasted.   I had the Chicken Saltimbocca which was very salty.   We also had a moderately priced bottle of wine and shared a scoop of gelato. All items were a la carte.  We agreed that the food was not memorable.  Although the owner was bustling about the small restaurant, he never stopped by our table to ask how things were or to wish us a happy holiday. It was not a warm or comfortable restaurant.  The one hundred and fifty dollar tab was way too steep for a mediocre meal.
author: MC B.

description: Ride the Powell Sr  Cable Car and hop off at Hyde/Pacicic Street.  Just a short stroll to Milano.  Quaint neighborhood restaurant with friendly staff and cooks.  For a antipastos...fresh calimari from Monterey.  Beet salad was outstanding.  Homemade pasta with porcini Italian sausage cream sauce was to die for.   Then their homemade ladyfinger tirimissu will float you to Heaven.
author: Wes Y.

description:
SIMPLE...FRESH....HOMEMADE AND DELICIOUS!!!!
Ristorante Milano is the bomb!  We have dined here twice during the past month.  Went back a second time because we wanted to see if the place was for real after an incredible first visit where we ate family style and shared many dishes.  Second visit was as good as the first.  The food bursts with fresh flavors.  You can taste all of the ingredients because they use very few.  Just the best fresh stuff available.  We love the Calamari with Cannaloni beans.  Asked the owner who is named Aldo how he makes the dish so fresh and delicious.  He told us he gets the calamari fresh each day and then simply grills it.  Amazing....the Butternut Squash Ravioli was one of the best pasta dishes of my life.  Everything we tried here was good.  Lasagna, Pasta with meat sauce, lamb chop and the Grilled Pear.....simply one of the best Italian restaurants we have ever visited.  simple, fresh ingredients cooked with years of experience.
author: Andrew S.

description: Food was good but not exceptional.  Service was very good.  The major problem is the noise.  If you're seated next to some old blowhards like us, it's awful-- even painful.
author: Michael C.

description:
Wandering around the Hyde Street area, my friend had passed by this little Italian restaurant many times and finally had the opportunity to dine there with me.

We chose a small table at the very back and up some stairs.  It was a bit of tight squeeze, as with all the other tables in this establishment.

The meal started with a very dense focaccia type bread and olive oil for dipping.  I had to hold off after one slice since I knew it was filling me up quickly.

We ordered the Antipasto Misto ($11.75), a selection of house made appetizers.  It included a quiche type thing, roasted peppers which were lovely, toasted bread with mozzarella, some red sauce on toasted bread, mushrooms, and olives.  It was an interesting mix and great for two people to share.  It would have been nice if they told us what all the appetizers were when the plate arrived.

For our entrees, we shared the Capelli d'Angelo al Filetto di Pomodoro ($11.95), which is homemade angel's hair prepared with fresh tomatoes, oil and garlic and the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa ($12.95), which is house made pasta in light cream sauce with porcini mushrooms and Italian sausage.  The capelli was a bit heavier on the sauce than I expected, but very tasty.  And the tonnarelli was very flavorful too.  The sausage was a bit ground up, and I think I expected more chunk-like pieces.  The portion sizes are okay.  It doesn't look like a whole lot.  I think if I didn't order an appetizer, I would have finished my entree quite easily.

Thinking I had not saved any room for dessert, I changed my mind once the (very cute) waiter told us the specials of the day.  I went with the  Poached peach with amaretto cookie crumbs and ice cream ($6.50) and my friend could not resist her favorite - Tiramisu ($6.50), which are ladyfingers dipped in rum and espresso layered with mascarpone and cocoa.  The peach was piping hot and a very light dessert that was calming to stomach after the heavy pasta dinner.  My friend was not impressed with the tiramisu.  Her biggest complaint was that there wasn't enough rum in it.  She could hardly taste any.  Since I'm not a tiramisu fan myself, I couldn't really say much about it expect that I still didn't like tiramisu.

Overall, the waitstaff is quite pleasant and nice.  Very friendly with smiles and everything.  So, I will give a big thumbs up on their positive attitude at this restaurant.  As I am a heavy water drinker, I did have to ask not once, but twice for my water glass to be refilled.

I wouldn't exactly call Ristorante Milano romantic.  It was loud in the main dining area and with all the tables so close together, you can hear everyone else's business.  It fills up pretty quickly on a weeknight, as with most of the decent restaurants around the Hyde Street area.

Overall, my friend and I felt this was a 3 star experience.  The food was good, not great.  You can tell you are getting a homemade experience, which is definitely nice.  When it came down to it, the food was just that - good, not fabulous.  

Side note: Restrooms - tiny!  No fat people allowed!  Tables are small for parties of two and it gets crowded on there right away, especially if you're sharing.
author: Teri C.

description:
Everyone talks about the gnocchi... which is FABULOUS! Light and airy, true puff perfections, offered with two different sauces (the tomato and basil was possibly some of the best sauce I've tasted). After eating the entire dish you wont feel disgusting and bloated, but instead happily satisfied (see I've said my piece about the gnocchi as well!). 

What I want to HIGHLIGHT is the Crostini ai Funghi-- yes that would be Mushroom Bruschetta. I don't believe people have given justice to it. It is hands down the best bruschetta I've tasted! Different from traditional tomato bruschetta, there are instead diced and perfectly seasoned mushrooms with Gorgonzola cheese. Although it's an appetizer I would've ordered another batch and eaten it again as my entree. Do not miss out on these! 

Service was very attentive without being overbearing. There is a quaint waiting area outside of the restaurant (a bench and tables/chairs with flowers about) which is nice if there is a wait. The environment feels like you become one of the family when you enter. Come here with anyone (even a blind date) because the environment exudes a warmth that will penetrate every diner!
author: Claire C.

description: Great date spot in SF. Cozy unpretentious restaurant with terrific food. Started with the bresaola and a special bruschetta, followed by ravioli and the lamb chops. We were too full for dessert, but they looked amazing. Wine list was reasonably priced as well.
author: Chris M.

description:
Had a wonderful meal here this week.  We went on Wednesday when most bottles of wine are 1/2 price!  We started with a fresh burrata cheese salad and an order of pan fried sardines.  Both were fresh and flavorful.  We shared brown butter and butternut squash raviolis and four cheese risotto as entrees.  Both were expertly prepared.  The flavors of the cheeses and rice all melted together perfectly yet each rice grain was soft and whole. A great find on Russian Hill.

Oh, forgot to add... the waiter was very attentive and personable.  Great service!
author: Seth G.

description: This is my family's favorite Italian restaurant in San Francisco. I love coming here so much because The wait staff is extremely friendly and I feel at home whenever dining here. The food is worth the pricing, portion sizes are perfect and I highly recommend the salads (and the tiramisu). I definitely recommend coming here over any restaurant in north beach :) thank you to Aldo and crew for such a great place to eat !
author: Evelyn D.

description:
I know, I know. Over 350 reviews with a 4 star average. I'd go back and give it a try on someone else's dime, as I can't imagine there are so many great reviews about this place...maybe I went on an "off" night? But really, when you shell out 75 bucks for dinner for 2, it's hard to dismiss it.

We started with the Sardine Gratinate- "fresh sardines lightly breaded and grilled". Yes, Monterey approved. No, they could not have been fresh. My boyfriend had one bite. I thought they tasted a little off, but was hungry and thought they'd get better as I went along...what was I thinking? It's not like a fine wine that "opens up" with time....my bad, as they didn't exactly sit well with me a few hours after dinner at all. My one-bite boyfriend was just fine.

We split the Risotto special with seafood. A few shrimps, mussels, and a mystery white fish. But what was really disappointing was the risotto. It had zero flavor, and might as well have come from a cardboard box meal. Watery, tasteless. I picked out the seafood and left the rice.

We also split the Veal Scaloppine with marsala and mushrooms. I thought it was just okay- it at least stood a chance, but nothing special.

Too bad we didn't go on a weekend where we could have had this lasagna that everyone raves about.
author: Lindsay K.

description: Great service! Delicious umbrian wine, delicious Gnocci. Just like Italy!! Yummy!!
author: Rachel C.

description:
We came at the peak of dinner hour and our water cups never went halfway empty - always full! :) Great attentive service.

Between two of us, we ordered 1 antipasto and 2 main courses. It was just the right amount of food. They also give you bread with olive oil, though I don't think either of us were fans. I'm usually a big bread eater but this one didn't have much flavor so it was easy to say 'no' to the carbs! :)

Tuna Carpaccio: Pretty presentation, but did not have very many flavors to it. I thought it was very warm compared to past tuna carpaccios that I've had. We squeezed all of the lemon on top hoping it would make the dish more zesty, but it still was seemingly flavorless.

Fettucine al Sugo di Carne alla Milanese: You must order with the homemade fettucini noodles. They give you green (spinach?) and plain ones combined with the red meat sauce so it gives it a really beautiful presentation. The flavor here was packed with yumminess! We were definitely both a fan and agreed it made up for the Tuna Carpaccio. I always feel guilty ordering spaghetti with meat at a restaurant because it's so cheap/easy to make at home, but I can safely say I could not replicate this.

Special of the day - Rissotto: The Rissotto was cooked to perfection. I'm not sure what was in it, but it had very mild flavors compared to the Fettucini alla Milanese. Nonetheless, it was tasty and we finished the entire dish! :)

The ambiance, service & authenticity gives this place 4 stars. :)
author: Emily L.

description:
I would give this 5 stars, but it is just in a local neighborhood and the prices are pretty high. I have been there twice and had fabulous meals each time. 

The fresh pasta is wonderful (I love gnocchi and it is hard to make in a restaurant) and the salad was great!

We were just staying on Nob Hill and wanted to walk somewhere so I looked it up on Yelp. Enjoyed it enough to go again with 2 teenagers (and  that is when I noticed the prices!)

I still highly recommend it because the service is good and the food is really good!
author: Michelle L.

description:
OVERALL:4.1   FOOD: 4.5   SERVICE:4   AMBIANCE:4   VALUE:4
Charming, cozy, lively & delicious!  A semi-hidden gem off the main Hyde-Polk drag that serves up fresh home-made pastas in vibrantly flavorful sauces ...and a mean tiramisu!

Tight quarters make for minimal elbow room and a intimately communal atmosphere that's good for both a social meal and/or romantic date.  Service is friendly, knowledgeable and often delivered with a nudge and wink...playful professionalism definitely makes for a smooth, enjoyable and comfortable experience (must be something to this whole Italian thing, eh?)
- http://www.yelp.com/biz/lupa-san-francisco#hrid:dtQWgO3leMcn6nomD_mgVg
- http://www.yelp.com/biz/capannina-san-francisco#hrid:CGgFTEsvV7BevM5nmaBWcg
- http://www.yelp.com/biz/caffe-baonecci-san-francisco-2#hrid:Jp_wF1rydSV029-ii_p4Ig

TONNARELLI ($17.95) 
Wow, I don't think I'll ever look at /eat Barilla the same way again--these home-made noodles were simply amazing!  Loved the woodsy porcini-sausage cream sauce!

PANCETTA / MUSHROOM LASAGNE SPECIAL ($18.95):
Home-made egg-noodle layers in a totally unique and memorable Bechamel cream sauce...not usually one for peas & ham, but this was heaven--hope it makes it back on the menu soon!

TIRAMISU ($7.50)
Mmmm...soft, lush, creamy & nutty!  Both the caffeine (espresso) & alcohol (rum) came in grown-up portions without being X-rated...a little racy, but still classy w/ a little left for imagination.
author: Amy K.

description:
Because of the actual atmosphere I  give this place three stars but the food is SO good.  This place has fresh amazing pasta. 

We started with the calamari from Monterey Bay.  Grilled with olive oil, salt, pepper, and lemon.  Not chewy like some grilled calamari can be and a great way to start off the night with.  Next I had the Pasta with sausage and mushrooms and OMG was it good.  My fiance had the lasagna which was light and fresh and delicious.  Both plates were piping hot and every last bite was eaten.

We couldn't possibly think of eating desert after our tummies being so full and happy.
author: Kylie L.

description:
A fun find on the edge of the Russian Hill area. Awesome service - friendly and accommodating. They have a small dining space but it's cozy and welcoming - no frills or cheese factor at work here.

The menu is solid, including some nice specials offered most nights. We missed out on the much-talked-about lasagna (sold out!), so that probably is worth checking out. The pasta options are flavorful, if not spectacular. This place is really worth checking out for the relaxed vibe and friendly staff. The food is good enough to avoid being disappointing.
author: Joel M.

description:
Came here on Valentine's Day, partly because they were one of the only restaurants that did not prix fixe menu which I appreciated. It was busy, but we still had great service. The atmosphere is intimate and was perfect for our date. They have a good wine list at a range of price points. 

As a vegetarian, I ordered the squash ravioli and it was EXCELLENT. Slightly sweet and delicious. Inspires me to cook more squash dishes at home. The boyfriend ordered the lasagna and said it was good as well. I would be happy to go back for another date night.
author: Molly W.

description: Great neighborhood Italian place, suitable for nice dates or casual dinners out.  A bit pricey, though, and with relatively slow service, but the food quality is high and the cozy atmosphere is inviting.  I usually come with reservations, but have still had to wait up to 20 minutes for a table.   Overall, 3.9 / 5 stars (can't quite bring myself to give it a full four).
author: Greg B.

description:
Nice neighborhood place.  

We started with an antipasto platter and tuna carpaccio.  Our very nice server reserved the last order of ravioli for us and it was yummy.

There was a half off special on wines under 60 dollars.

Tables are extremely close together but felt more cozy than suffocating.
author: Poppy C.

description:
4.5 stars.

I wish someone could design a quiet, intimate, romantic, off the beaten track Italian restaurant with an owner from Italy, a well-informed and completely unpretentious wait staff, a friendly and unfussy atmosphere, a focused menu, understated decor, and a strong sense of place.

I would also really like it if it were in a location that made me feel like I accidently discovered it while walking past with my wife, even though it has been a neighborhood institution for 3 decades. 

I wish the food could be comprised of a perfectly balanced combination of old and new, with great pasta options and gnocchi to die for.

Oh, wait. Somebody already did.
author: Blue B.

description:
Ristorante Milano is one of my favorite restaurants in the city! I know most people would go to North Beach to enjoy a classic Italian meal however this restaurant to me is the most authentic.

Everything is made with the finest ingredients and the dishes remind me of Milanese cuisine much more northern italian. Homemade pastas and the chicken is well prepared. I usually get the gnocchi as a nice appetizer.
author: Maria M.

description:
Came here with an old friend for dinner on a Tuesday night. The restaurant is in a nice location, typical Nob Hill restaurant aside from the boldly metallic facade. Inside ambiance is quaint and relaxed, makes for a good date spot but I wouldn't recommend it for groups.

We had the air-cured beef and bruschetta for appetizers. Neither was very good or bad, just so-so. Thankfully after that it got much better. I ordered the gnocchi and my friend ordered the chicken saltimbocca. Both were delicious, and our server had recommended a $30 bottle of sangiovese that went perfectly with our meal.  We split the tiramisu for dessert and were impressed yet again, definitely some of the best I've ever had.

Service was a bit slow at first but definitely good, and the free bread they serve is tasty. Definitely recommend this for anyone in the area.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Oh yum!  Wandered in on a packed Friday night and got lucky.  We were seated in about 15 minutes.

It could be the company, but I this was part of my best night ever.  Every moment was fun and romantic and I giggled like a teenager.  You gotta try the ravioli.

By the time we got dessert the wine was blurry my memory.  I still inhaled my tiramisu.  I stumbled out happy and full.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Came here the last two NYE's for dinner.  Man this place is good!  Great food, great ambiance, and great service.  Only compliant is the seating is very tight here but I guess doing that get more seats and in turn feeds me sooner! :)
author: Tito P.

description: My brother, his wife, and I decided to come here on a whim and I am glad we did. The food was amazing; The bread was soft and fluffy and the pasta was delicious. Along with that, we had amazing service. The wait staff was extremely friendly and they refilled our drinks instantly. I would recommend this place in a heartbeat.
author: Scott R.

description:
The night's appetizer special Strawberry salad was PHENOMENAL. Funny to say about an Italian restaurant this fine but it's in San Francisco and California so this aspect adds to a menu a twist I suspect wouldn't be offered in Milan.

I enjoyed the Cappelli D'Angelo and my friend had the Boar Ravioli  which he loved. 

I wish I could remember the dessert special we shared and drooled over because it was one of the best complements to a meal that I've ever enjoyed. Something like a mousse/amaretto soaked cakelet. 

This restaurant was recommended to us unsolicited by a local on the street who saw me looking at my iPhone while standing at a street corner near Lombard Street.

I live in Manhattan and see it as a community service to provide directions when asked and recommendations as well. Reciprocally, I welcome them and trust them when offered while I'm traveling.

Mr. Nob Hill, if you read this, thank you. We were headed to another recommended restaurant in North Beach when you stopped us to point out the 4- and 5-star restaurants on Hyde Street south of Lombard. Then you told us to find Milano. Thank you. This was a Rick Steves' moment of diving in to trust local experts.

Also, thanks to Milano. We didn't have a reservation but you honored your 30 minute wait after we waited it out at the Enoteca on the next corner at Hyde & Pacific.

In every way this was a delightful travel and dining experience.
author: Sally B.

description:
I ate here for the first time last night and I realllly wanted to like the food since it's close to my house and a cute little place. 
Ordered the polenta, mozzarella and roasted peppers appetizer. Each part was great on its own but put together it was strange. I didn't like it. 
I had the butternut squash risotto as my main & it was fine. Something I could easily make at home. I wished there was more of a butternut squash taste, the only squash-y part of it was the color. However the mushrooms in it were good. It was an orange mushroom risotto. My dining companion ordered the lasagna. I wish I had ordered that. It was pretty good. 
Nothing horrible but nothing outstanding either.
author: Sara P.

description:
Ambiance: Small and warm.
Service: Servers are so nice.

Food: Amazing bread with olive oil.
My favorite one is grilled calamari appetizer. It is an amazing dish ever. I eat that all the time.

Mixed or combo cold appetizer plate was okay. Nothing special. They just put the all canned mushrooms, red peppers, eggplant, and so on in a plate. 

Main course: I had rabbit. I think, it did not have any special taste. It is just okay. I could not finish it, It could be better.
Another time, i had mixed grill. It was overcooked, actually it was literally "burned". I cut the burned parts and i tried to eat the rest. 
My friend had pasta with mussels, it was better than what i had.

Dessert:  Tiramisu , yummyyyyyy!

Because bread, grilled calamari, tiramisu, and the service were good, I gave just 3 stars.
author: Tugce e.

description: I had the gnocchi which was so fluffy and delicious and the vodka cream sauce it was in was very delicious. My chardonnay was also very delicious. The service was very good and the ambiance was lovely!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
awesome food. I had their Lasagna and I can honestly say it was the most authentic Italian lasagna I've had in the US (and I used to live in Italy so I know a thing or two about Italian food) 
I came out of there supremely satisfied.
author: Rachael T.

description:
I read so many glowing 5 star reviews about Milano, it was our civic duty to finally eat here.  Russian Hill parking - maddening, impossible.  Take muni or pay for parking somewhere down on Van Ness and hike up the hill.  

Our table reservation promptly honored. Friendly greeting then quickly seated in the cramped front window room.  Busy Sunday night, took the waiter 25 minutes to take our orders. 

Romano salad was light, fresh, & crunchy. Minestrone / Lentil soup with homemade beef stock equally good. Lasagna was sauted style, not the baked gummy mess you get in Americanized places.  Good but not great, a little watery tasting.  Linguini with cream sauce was over powerfully rich - But Yum!  Ricotta tart was warm and tasty.  

Small glasses of wine at $10-$12 each are overpriced. Bill for 90 minutes of fun = $114.

Verdict: Very good food, nice people, cramped & crowded room. Smallest public toilet  in San Francisco. 

I like Antica Trattoria located 2 streets away better.
author: Tom S.

description: Awesome Food, Awesome Service. Can not wait until our next trip to San Francisco because we will be going back!
author: Rose P.

description: This place was just ok. It's homemade pasta, but I didn't really see anything special about it. I had the fettuccine. Honestly, I thought it was a little overpriced for what it was. It wasn't bad, but it's not something I would make an effort to go back for.
author: Kerry K.

description:
First review/comments after joining Yelp. I read a lot of reviews to determine where to eat in San Francisco prior to our arrival and for the first night after traveling from the east coast we wanted something close to our hotel and nothing fancy so we chose Ristorante Milano.  The restaurant is small, no problem, the staff is very friendly and service was excellent however the meal we got was average at best.  Maybe one doesn't get seafood at an Italian restaurant but my wife's swordfish fillet was very bland and no flavor.  I'm use to a swordfish steak not a fillet where it is 3/4 to 1" thick and this was 1/4 to 3/8" thick and tasted like it was boiled with parsley sprinkled on top.  I'm sure not a food critic but I would not return.  The owner or manager did ask us how we liked our meal and what we thought.  We told him and he did remove the entree from the bill.

I got a calamari appetizer that was very good and my entree was a "stew" with mussels, shrimp and  scallops over rice that was okay but nothing great.

Maybe it was just a bad night for us as the other reviews have been very good and is the reason we chose here to eat.  I would not get the swordfish fillet if you decide to go.
author: Tom G.

description:
My friends and I went here to celebrate two of our 30th birthdays.  A girls' night out in SF.  It was fun for a small group.  The restaurant is small, and pretty cramped.  I was stuck in a corner near no windows and no way to get out of my seat unless the person beside me got up.  Also, I don't know what they wax their floors with, but don't wear high heals to this place.  Walking through the restaurant felt like walking on a greased runway!

The service was great.  I never felt like I had to look for our server, because she was always around.  Not hovering, but definitely attentive!

I ordered the gnocchi.  Soft, homemade deliciousness.  The tomato sauce was very sweet, and I opted for no gorgonzola.  The bruschetta was amazing.  I can't describe it.  I had to contain myself and not grab all of it off the shared plate to stuff it in my mouth before anyone else took more.  It was a special, but if you go there try and order it!   One of my friends ordered the lasagna.  It wasn't that impressive.  The bread is also just okay.

The tiramisu, Oh god, so good.  It was creamy, not too sweet.  The perfect ending to a solid Italian meal.

If you are in the neighborhood and looking for Italian, this is a great choice.  However, I wouldn't forgo trying other restaurants just to go back.  We actually ended up here because we couldn't get reservations to some other restaurants we were interested in. For that situation, it ended up being great.
author: Tara G.

description: My lasagna was really light and fluffy.  I was hoping for more of a substantial meal, but given that it was so extremely delicious, I'm still giving the place 4 stars.  Wonderfully yummy food.
author: Jean Z.

description:
What a great find!  I love this place!
Again, when I was moving to SF, my SF native friends in NYC warned me that good Italian food would be a hard find in SF.
God is watching over me because I have found a place that rivals any good Italian restaurant in NYC...and I've had a lot of Italian in my 12 years in NYC!

1. Ambiance - I was with a party of 5 and we had the charming table by the window.  It was private but still not disconnected from the restaurant.
2. Service - the staff was very attentive but not overbearing.  One of the things I can't stand in a restaurant is when the staff tries to "push" you out.  The waitstaff at Milano let us take our time with ordering, eating, dessert, everything!  They were so friendly and helpful it was a great experience.
3. Food - 
a) Appetizer: we ordered the antipasto misto which is an assortment of appetizers that came with the following highlights:
zucchini and carrot fritatta - moist but not wet, very flavorful
polenta cake with mozzarella, olive and tomato tapanade - YUM!

b) Main course: I had the fettucine al Sugo di Carne alla Milanese (meat sauce) and it was great!  Often times, these meat sauces are too salty for me, but tonight it was just right!  The plate came out steaming and the noodles portion was perfect with plenty of sauce left over for dipping with bread!
My fiance had the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa - pasta in light cream sauce with Porcini Mushrooms and Italian sausage...this was perfect!  Neither the mushrooms or sausage was overbearing and it wasn't a cream heavy sauce...everything was perfect!

This is a true find!
author: S K.

description: We have eaten at Ristorante Milano many times, and again last night. As always, the food and service were impeccable . . . a true "neighborhood gem".
author: T M.

description:
Got a reservation for four one Thursday night at 7, which we really didn't need.  Service was excellent, glasses were filled regularly, etc. 

I got the beet and asparagus salad and gnocchi- both were delicious! Everyone else ordered daily specials, and no one was disappointed.  All in all, cute little spot I'd go back to.
author: Karina P.

description: Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa is THE BEST PASTA I'VE TASTED IN THE WORLD.  There I said it.... I can't think of some place I've had better ... although eating in Rome was quite amazing but I didn't know where to eat... anyhow simply amazing.
author: Albert W.

description:
This restaurant is a decent Italian restaurant.  I've eaten here 3 times, pay attention to the specials they usually are the best thing on the menu.  Once I had pumkin ravioli with brown sugar, it really was phenomenal but alas, it's not on the menu.

The portions can be quite large, but they are tasty.  This is a fairly small restaurant and parking is horrendous.
author: Shen J.

description: What a truly magnificent gem of an Italian restaurant! Certainly a local favorite with warmth and ambiance that only San Francisco has to offer. Our server Rob was helpful in recommending a Burrata cheese first course with shaved fennel, Arugula and a vinaigrette. My wife had the infamous Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa and I tried the Lamb chops. To finish off the meal, Tiramisu and a chocolate gelato that can only be compared to genuine Italian gelato I had in Rome. It is a family owned business and the owner's daughter was present in good spirit and support of the restaurant. The meal was reasonably priced and on the mark.
author: Alex C.

description:
Benvenuto!  We recently had the pleasure of dining at Milano for the first time.  We were introduced to this Russian Hill neighborhood jewel by a long-time 20-year local patron.  When I heard that this place had been around for so long and I never even knew about it...I realized truly how much more exploring of the vast SF restaurant scene I had to do.

Thankfully, I can now add Milano to my list of "Go To" restaurants when I am in the mood for some really good Italian fare.

From the Insalata di Radicchio to the homemade Gnocchi to the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa, everything was supremely tasty and fresh.  Take my word that the pasta here is truly phenomenal...makes generic spots like Pasta Pomodoro taste like Chef Boyardee.

Chiati Classico and the desserts all perfectly complement your meal.  Top everything off with excellent service to boot and you've definitely got a spot that will swipe my VISA more than once!

Ristorante Milano...Magnifico!
author: Justin L.

description:
I wanted to give Ristorante Milano and its staff big props for accommodating my friends and I over Memorial Day weekend. We waited until the last minute on a Sunday night to make reservations. Little did we know it was prom night and just about every restaurant in town was booked. Milano was the only restaurant I called that was willing to squeeze in our party of 6 on 20 minutes notice. They even re-arranged their seating in the loft for us (though, that made going to the restroom tricky). 

The staff was very friendly and attentive. The food was buenisimo! I had the fettucine alla ghiotta and it was one of the most heavenly things I have ever eaten. The sauce was so rich and creamy, with great flavors that really complimented the Italian sausage in it. My friend had ordered the gnocchi and after having a bite of mine, she said she had wished she had ordered the fettucine instead. Two people in our party had the special ravioli filled with boar. One thought it was great the other wasn't wowed. We topped off dinner with a duo of their housemade sorbets. The pear sorbet was very rich and smooth and not overly sweet. The raspberry was a bit more granulated, probably from too much sugar but still good, I just preferred the pear.

Great intimate spot for a delicious Italian dinner. I just recommend making a reservation well in advance because this place is always bumpin' even on a Sunday night! Oh, and additional kudos for being patient while our math whiz divvied up the check.
author: Lorraine L.

description: Sensational genuine Italian. Everything we had was made with care and attention including quality ingredients that you really taste. Highlights were the bruschetta, chestnut and brown butter ravioli, strawberry sorbet and the montepulciano wine.
author: Ryan B.

description:
The apps were good, the wine was good, but I knew I was a fan when I had the first bite of my entree.

Have you ever been served a pasta with a tomato sauce and upon seeing that sight feeling remorse for having ordered a plain pasta with a bland red sauce that doesn't even stick to the pasta? 

This has happened to me countless times, but wowie, wowie! I was served a pasta with a tomato sauce and the first bite was light, but with depth, rich, but bright, and had the right amount of spiciness. I just couldn't get enough of the sauce. It was SO flavorful. I was impressed.

I plan to return to try more items off the menu, I suggest you do the same.
author: Miss B.

description: I can see why they don't have lasagna on the regular menu   The sauce tasted like chef boyardee  spaghetti and meatballs.  also the bread was awful tasted like some old wonder bread.  Only good thing were the gnchocci
author: Shawn H.

description:
Can't think of any complaints! 5 of us ate here last night & all ordered different things on the menu so that we could taste several different dishes. We started with the Burrata & an arugula salad, the fegatini alla griglia, and the antipasto misto. Of the 3 starters, the burrata was my favorite- hands down. 

For dinner we ordered the gnocchi, butternut squash filled ravioli, lasagna, the risotto off the specials menu, and the fresh fish dish of the day- black cod. We passed them around family style- my 2 favorites were the gnocchi & ravioli. My least favorite of the 5 was the risotto, but even it was still good. 

For desert we had the tiramisu & a ricotta cheesecake (I think...). The tiramisu was awesome. 

Great, cozy place with good service. Would recommend making a reservation because the place is small. If you arrive early- go have a glass of wine at Cafe Meuse on the corner of Hyde & Pacific.
author: Jenna R.

description: This place was stellar.  It's small, modern, and has incredible food! Get the butternut squash ravioli--you wont regret it.
author: Erin F.

description:
Sometimes a great evening sneaks up on you, and you find yourself in the middle of unexpected happiness and contentment.

This will likely come from the company you keep, but will certainly be aided by your surroundings - a destination, an establishment, any standard physical setting. 

Ristorante Milano is a sweet, tucked-away little place in Nob Hill. The setting is smooth and quaint, upscale without being fancy and casual without being unkempt. The food is very good - warm, classic, comforting Italian fare - paired aptly between Russian River Valley pinot noir and espresso shaved ice. 

Just lovely.
author: Anna G.

description: Very good atmosphere. Food was good quality, but could have been more flavorful. My wife ordered the seafood risotto special and found the mussels to be fishy/not fresh tasting.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Shame on me for waiting so long to write this review.  When I leave Sonoma County and head for the city I go to Milano!  I've had two birthday dinners/celebrations there and the staff is so friendly and lively, without being over-animated.  

I won't bother with a red sauce anywhere else.  Last night's marinara sauce was brilliant with a rich almost smokey meat flavor.  The salads are amazing and my favorite dessert is the cheesecake made with ricotta cheese...had it last night and it was perfect as always.  Aldo and his staff make me feel like I'm in my own neighborhood restaurant in Italy sipping rich red wine.  

And somehow that tired old song "Happy Birthday" sounds so much nicer in Italian.
author: F B.

description: Food here was very good. The buratta was tasty and the pasta was delicious. The restaurant is pretty small and we had probably the worst table in the restaurant.
author: Scoot S.

description:
This is a spot I probably would never have tried if it weren't for my roommate recommending it. It's on a residential block, rather inconspicuously might I add, and as far as I know is flying a little under the radar with the exception of the Russian/Nob Hill dwellers.

I can see why this is a hot neighborhood spot. It has authentic Italian food; no frills, bells or whistles, just hearty specialized goodness. My mother and I ordered two dishes: the lamb shank and the beet/ricotta ravioli's with butter sauce (it was a special). Both were great but in all honestly, I loved my friend's dish the best! She ordered the Angel Hair and Tomato Sauce. Usually I wouldn't even bat an eye in that item's direction but there was something so comforting and special about it. Maybe it was due to the abundance of flavorful sauce it was tossed in (I love me some sauce!)? If I ever go back, that's what I'm ordering!
author: Julia N.

description: hands-down best pasta I have ever had in my life so far. even better than Italy tbh.
author: Paul L.

description:
Best gnocchi I have ever had. It is a must
Pastas were good
Bread below average
Carpaccio ok
Wonderful Authentic service
Great neighborhood spot
author: Sara B.

description:
3.5 stars

Ristorante Milano makes some yummy things, although it doesn't live up to its high Zagat ratings of old (it used to be 26, now a 23). I wonder if the quality has gone down over the years or if San Franciscans have merely decided better options exist. 

My major gripe is Milano's prices. They are too high for what seems like a neighborhood restaurant, even though it is located in an expensive neighborhood. Entrees range in price up to $30 and nothing is ever stellar. I tried a Veal Marsala-like dish for $30 at Milano and it was inferior to a similar dish that is $10 less at Nob Hill Cafe (same neighborhood, if not nicer). 

I don't want to decide to not cook one night, walk a few blocks, and then have an impromptu $80 meal. It feels too lavish for a 24 year old research assistant whose parents are probably at home eating a Whole Foods rotisserie chicken. 

The best thing I've had at Milano was a very simple fettucine with meat sauce. It didn't blow my mind, but it was very satisfying (except of course too expensive). The other things I've liked were a bruschetta special and the espresso granita dessert. Both were pretty darn good.

The service is very nice and the waitress we've had every time we've been there is cute, warm, and totally welcoming. I wouldn't say Milano is a destination restaurant, but if you wind up in the neighborhood hungry with money to burn, it's a good option.
author: Amanda C.

description:
The atmosphere is really nice. the food is delicious.  It feels a bit like an authentic Italian family restaurant.  the wait staff is very nice, and the food prices are reaonable.

Four instead of five stars because the menu is a bit limited, so it get's boring after a few visits, but it is definitely worth one or two visits.
author: Weyl E.

description: This is not a good restaurant. Food was lousy. Service was non attentive. And it's way too expensive for what you're getting. There's nothing worse than leaving a restaurant after spending a $100 and having a sucky meal.
author: Brandon S.

description: Rip-off! Horrible! Mislabeled dishes! I started with the Insalata Mista - $9, which was okay but unremarkable. My mother had the Linguine ai Frutti di Mare  - house-made linguine with fresh shellfish in a white sauce - $25. The seafood was fine but the white sauce turned out to be a rank, foul-tasting light brown broth. The linguine noodles were blase, and covered in grease from the broth. My mother and I agreed the awful broth ruined the dish. My aunt, visiting from Arkansas, had the Fettucine al Sugo di Carne alla Milanese - house-made fettucine with Milanese meat - $19, which she liked. I found it okay but tasteless and lacked any meat. I had the Scallopine di Vitello - milk-fed veal scaloppine of the day - $33. This was the worst dish of the night. It tasted horrible, it wasn't veal, and it was really veal parmigiana without the veal!! It had a very funky flavor. I stopped the waiter and asked him if this dish was veal, he said it was. I told him the dish tasted weird, he replied, "It's made with smoked mozzarella." What??? First off, it was not veal scaloppine, it was fake-veal parmigiana. The fake-veal was tasteless beyond the funky flavor - I suspect it was tofu or some artificial meat. My mother thought it was some processed fake meat. It definitely was NOT veal - I've had veal hundreds of time and cooked it numerous times. Second, it was not scallopine - the fake-meat was covered in melted cheese and topped with tomato sauce - fake-veal parmigiana! I would have sent it back but I didn't want to create a scene in front of my visiting aunt who we had not seen in decades. For dessert, my aunt had the pistachio gelato, and liked it, but like I wrote she's lives in Arkansas. My mother had the chocolate torte and liked it. My mother had a glass of Proseco - $13, which was decent, and a cup of coffee. I had a glass of unremarkable Chianti - $12. My aunt drank water. Before tip, our meal was $134.07. After we dropped off my aunt at her hotel, my mother and I discussed the meal and felt we got totally ripped off. Perhaps other reviewers were too loaded or unfamiliar with good northern Italian cuisine to know what it is supposed to taste like. Save your palette and your money and go somewhere else!!
author: Jim B.

description:
Great service and the food is good. I has the lasagna an i'm not normally
a lasagna guy.  I ordered it because it was recommended by so many Yelpers. And I don't regret it. It was very good. Others I was with had fettucine bolognese and it was very good. Also the chicken with prosciutto was excellent. 

I give this place an enthusiastic thumbs up.
author: M T.

description:
Honestly, this is a 4.5 star rating, but alas.  We went here for my dad's bday dinner and we were all very impressed. My parents are definite foodies so impressing them is a huge compliment. I like to think of myself as a foodie as well, but on a more picky & limited scale :)

The ambiance was very nice. The place is almost too small though as you feel a little cramped especially on a weekend when you really want to just kind of let loose.  BUT, the staff are extremely personable and funny and just very authentic. The main gentleman that I believe owns or runs it made it his point to ensure that we enjoyed the meal and we definitely felt taken care of.
