Now on to the food!  The food was delicious.  I had the gnocci with gorgonzola & cream (substituted for the tomato & basil sauce) and it was delicious with the perfect consistency and the gorgonzola was so flavorful...My parents shared a meal and loved their food.  My husband loved his seafood risotto, as well. 

I had blueberry sorbet, and it was definitely flavorful, very little sugar so very natural tasting.  

The only criticism my mom had was that her pour of wine could have been a little more generous, but she noted that she was very pleased other than that minor detail. They will definitely be going back & I hope to return soon.
author: Jenna K.

description: Always spot on - for a decade (probably more).  My wife is from Milan, and while the food may be from a few regions in Italy, this is the place that never has failed to represent in every way.  Do yourself a favor and check it out.
author: jeff f.

description: We loved this restaurant!  The food was amazing and the service was very friendly. It reminded us of Italy. We would definitely go back.
author: Claire K.

description:
Made a reservation here when my first choice was closed for a private party. We live two blocks away and I've been wanting to try it for a while now. A fellow commuter and italian fare connoisseur recommended this place to me saying that I "live right next door to some of the best italian food in sf."

I bought tickets to the American Bach Soloists performance of Handel's Messiah at Grace Cathedral and we stopped by here to eat beforehand. Our waiter, Raphael, was a personable, perfect gentleman with a huge appreciation for the food and made sure we ordered the right dishes for a great meal. We started off with the sardines as an appetizer. It comes with shaved fennel, onion salad and fresh lemon. The sardines are lightly breaded and cooked perfectly. Raphael even served the plate dividing the dish up equally between the two of us. I decided to try one of the pasta specials, butternut squash ravioli, and my husband chose the spaghetti special with seafood. Both were amazing. I tried to finish my husband's plate as he filled up on bread. Next time I definitely want to save room for dessert.

Can't wait to go again when my parents come into town! There were too many good choices on the menu!
author: Nicole Sooah C.

description:
We found Ristorante Milano while wandering around Russian Hill last Friday night. Actually our noses found it! To our surprise, we only had to wait a few minutes to be seated. On a Friday night I was expecting to wait in the bar with a cocktail, which isn't always a bad thing! 

The staff was very friendly. Our waitress was great; full of suggestions and details about each of the dishes we asked about.

We started with some of the best (maybe THE best) grilled calimari I've ever had. Next came a giant plate of Gnocchi with a gorgonzola cream sauce that was quite tasty. I wish I had saved room for dessert. The tiramisu at the next table looked great (I was tempted to ask for a taste!).
author: John F.

description: Ordered the seafood special that my waiter recommended.  It was OK not great.  Service and ambiance was great.
author: Jeff S.

description:
It had been a while since I've been to Milano. I knew it had become pretty popular and was worried the food might suffer because of it. I went early to avoid the rush of people (yes, even on a Tuesday night, Milano will fill up by about 7:30, but they do take reservations). It turns out I didn't have much to worry about.

For appetizers we had the bruschetta special which was delish and served with mozerella, tomatoes and olives. It was very flavorful and when all of the different flavors combined it was like biting into a warm summers day. Also for apps I was feeling a bit adventurous and ordered the Fegatini alla Griglia (chicken livers and bacon w/ radicchio). I would call this fair. The radicchio went well with the livers but the meat was left on the flame a little too long and instead of being smoked was more like burnt. Which is too bad because I think smoky bacon would have complimented it very well. 

For the main course we both got the gnocchi and I was very happy when it came out just as light and airy as I remembered. Like little pillows of goodness melting in your mouth. I still think Milano has the best gnocchi in the city. 

For dessert we got the tiramisu and the little pick me up was great. After my very disappointing tiramisu experiences in Seattle I was really hoping for a good showing and Milano delivered. Served with ladyfingers that were soaked in espresso, large layers of light and fluffy cheese filling and given a wonderful dusting of cocoa on top, it's a piece of goodness on a plate. 

Yes, it's a little pricey. If you order an app, entrée, dessert and a little wine you're looking at $40-$50 a person. If the price scares you off, just order an entree and leave with a $20-$25 bill.
author: Russ C.

description: Dinner was fair. The presentation of food was beautiful but the flavor was ordinary. We tried gnocchi and, ravioli and linguini. The pastas were all very heavy- not what we expected. The restaurant is very loud. Difficult to visit with your party. The waiter was very cordial but so soft spoken we could barely hear him recite the specials. Desserts were disappointing. Good cappuccino. Nice location. But have eaten at much better places in the city.
author: Patti A.

description:
What a nice little surprise!! A small neighborhood restaurant (off the beaten path) that serves wonderful and delicious Italian food. I would go as far as to say the best Italian food I've had in SF in some time. It's a small restaurant with big flavor! The simple ambiance of the place reminded me of NY. Why go to North Beach for Italian when this place exists?! 

Next time I go I'm ordering the lasagna, unfortunately they were sold out of it by the time we sat down for dinner. However, the dish I ordered (the gnocchi) was out of this world!! Yummy! Dinner followed immediately with heavenly profiteroles. All of this delicious food and wonderful service, what more could you ask for.
author: Amanda P.

description: We had a lovely meal here for my husband's birthday.  Great food, great service; their tiny busy bathroom was the only negative.
author: Christine B.

description: Great atmosphere for a date or a get-together with friends or family. The menu is interesting and the wine list is vast. The staff were wonderful. It's not very spacy and we were bumping elbows with the party next to us and the waiter's butt as he went over their service with them. The food was okay... We got the meat platter, which was overcooked, and the mushroom spaghetti, which was superb. The tiramisu is to-die-for! Good experience, but not somewhere I absolutely HAVE to back to.
author: Convict T.

description: Visiting SF for business trip.  This was my second visit to Ristorante Milano in the last year.  Food was wonderful and service was engaged and warm.  This is a small neighborhood restaurant where I would expect and saw familiarity as patrons arrived.  Great spot for a small business group or that special someone.
author: Stephen L.

description: Romantic family restaurant with really wonderful food. I love the air aged beef appetizer. Only reason it loses a star is the dessert. Its good but not excellent. I tried the special puff pasty. It was good but again, not excellent.
author: Natalie W.

description:
I haven't been back since July of 2007, but this place has one of the most memorable gnocchi I've had. 

YES, yes, yes! The gnocchi was delicious. Besides flavor, texture is so important to me in food. Their gnocchi is soft and a little on the fluffier side. Since I've never had success in making gnocchi at home, I tend to order it when I go to Italian restaurants. It's kind of been a big defining factor for me. 

The pasta is homemade and the restaurant seems to be family run. Even so, it carries a casual romantic atmosphere. Good for dates!

I will definitely be going back soon and posting an update!
author: Joyce L.

description:
I love this place. The food is good, the pasta is fresh, the ambiance is perfect.

Reminds me of being in Italy and having a fabulous dinner. I love their pasta. In fact, I am eating here the night before my first marathon this Sunday.

The flavors are great, service is great. What I really like about this place is that I never feel rushed. I can sit and relax and really enjoy my meal. The owner is always there and stops by the table and says hello.

I love this neighborhood resultant and I am so glad that it isn't in North Beach flooded with tourist.
author: sierra s.

description: Really enjoyed the food here. Good Italian option for Nob Hill. The gnocchi wasn't the best but everything else was very tastey!! Had the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa for an entree.
author: Jenna S.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner with friends and it was perfect.  Very cosy, beautiful interior, delicious food, friendly service :)
author: Rachel W.

description: Great service!  Great food...  enjoyed our time.  Arrived just in time restaurant filled to capacity by 630pm...  My daughter enjoyed her pasta dish and the chocolate gelato....
author: Steven P.

description: I love this place. The food is superb. Feels like authentic italian, tastes like authentic italian. Good service, great food. Make reservations on weekends, since it's a pretty small, quaint little place.
author: Kate H.

description:
The boy and I came here for an anniversary a month ago based off of stellar Yelp reviews, like most of the other people here.

Personally, I found the entire restaurant really quaint. We had a reservation at 7pm, and we got there a few minutes early. The place was already fairly hopping for a Saturday night. If you're looking for a restaurant with plenty of space between separate parties, this isn't the place for you. I was practically sharing a table with the people on either side of me. That would be the only negative I have with the place, personally.

The boy and I shared a vegetarian appetizer that was delicious. I honestly wish I could remember the name of the appetizer, but it's been a month. For the main dish, I had the cheese ravioli at the recommendation of our waitress and the boy had the gnocchi. Both was heavenly delicious. The ravioli were bigger than they appeared on the plate initially and the gnocchi simply melted away in my mouth. We had a dessert, too, but I can't remember what it was.. I just remember there being chocolate and it being heavenly and telling myself that the boy deserved to get something special for bringing me to such a delicious place.

I would definitely go again if I could. Parking is hard to find, so plan ahead (we had taxi'd there) and I would definitely recommend making reservations first or else you're subjected to wait time. Not for big groups, unless you guys like rubbing elbows with every John, Dick and Henry that sits next to you.
author: Anna W.

description:
This place is so overpriced for the food quality!  We have so much good food in the city that I am surprised this place is still in business.  

It is a neighborhood spot for me and I will never go back.

The food is bland and priced like you are at Boulevard.  I would suggest walking around the corner to Coccotte.
author: Liz M.

description: My gf and I grabbed dinner here Friday night.  The wine list was impressive, and the service was spectacular.  We both ordered off the menu, and our server was very accommodating.  The place was full, but not too loud.  We will definitely be back.
author: Matthew B.

description:
Real home-made pasta, fresh ingredients,mostly meet for the entrees and a mix for the antipasti... my fellas ordered the pasta with the Ox-tail and it was fantastic, y like their menu, short list of items so you dont get lost about what to order.. 
The tiramisú was light and tasty..perfect end for a nice dinner
author: Aneli C.

description:
3.5 stars.

We went to Ristorante Milano last weekend with my parents and aunt and uncle based off of Yelp recommendations. I wouldn't say it was as great as everyone says, but I did enjoy my meal. 

For appetizers we had Bruschetta, Calamari & mozzarella. All were a variation of what we are used to: Bruschetta was with mushrooms, Calamari came with beans (but I thought was really good) and the mozzarella was served on polenta. I liked them all, but they weren't what I was expecting.

For dinner, I had the gnocchi which I really liked. It was cooked just right and melted in my mouth. I'm a gnocchi lover and they made this well. They only had one type of beer (Peroni) which was a bit disappointing after a day of wine tasting when we wanted something else. 

In terms of ambiance, it's hard to tell. I think it would normally be great, but there was a party of 12-15 people close by that were *really* loud so it was hard to hear each other. At least it sounded like they were having fun.

Overall, I would go again but will probably try a few new Italian places in North Beach first because I didn't think it was overly special.
author: Katie W.

description:
I had the Scaloppine di Vitello, and the veal was cooked perfectly.  I gotta say though, I could not stop stealing bites of my sister's gnocchi!  I've been burned by bad gnocchi before (chewy & disgusting), but this stuff was FANTASTIC.  Practically melted in your mouth.  We were there for my birthday, so our group of four splurged and ordered a few desserts - the tiramisu was to DIE for, and the pear sorbet was incredibly refreshing.  Our server was attentive without hovering too much - he kept my wine glass filled, so I was a happy camper.  

The only thing that I didn't like was that the tables are so darn close together.  Like seriously, 6 inches of space between our table and the table next to us.  I'm cool with communal dining, but I like to know about it prior to sitting down, thanks.
author: Christy S.

description:
I had dinner at Ristorante Milano while in SF on business in September.  
Ordered the Saltimbocca di Pollo and a glass of Italian white; my review in a nutshell, the sauce on the chicken was incredible and the prosciutto really comes through to make this a wonderful entree.  I've not been to Italy, but dine at a lot of Italian restaurants.  I would put this one on my best I've been to list.

The restaurant had a very cozy neighborhood feel and is just off the Hyde Street trolley route at Pacific Ave.  I was in SF for a week and dined out every night; this was one of the two best restaurants that week.
author: Guy K.

description:
Dropped by here last night.  As other reviews have indicated, this place is tiny, and really only good for small parties.  The tables are extremely close together, and the place is quite noisy, meaning we felt like we were dining at the same table as all of our neighbors.  So ambiance, not that great, but the service was very good.

Of course, the thing everybody really cares about is the food.  They started us with some awesome looking bread that unfortunately wasn't near as good tasting as it looked.  It was dry and crumbly and maybe a bit stale?  However, olive oil and balsamic vinegar make even mediocre bread decent.  We had the calamari appetizer with cannelloni beans, which was very good, but also very expensive for what we got.  I had the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa (recommended by others here), and was generally pleased.  It wasn't the best pasta ever, but it was fresh and tasty and not overbearing.  If you've ever had the Archers Farms mushroom pasta from Target, the flavor was very similar to that, except with much better ingredients.  My girlfriend had the fettuccine with sausage and tomatoes and the flavor was rather subtle and a bit understated.  It wasn't bad, but she was a bit disappointed.

The high point of the meal was really dessert.  We got the poached pear done in a Marsala reduction with pear sorbet, and it was fantastic.  I highly recommend it to anybody and everybody.

The plates here range from about $17 - $30, and the cheapest wine they have is $9 per glass.  We're pretty frugal eaters, but after our $18ish meals, two glasses of wine, an appetizer, desert, tax and tip, we had spent close to $100.

Overall, a decent experience, but nothing special, and $100 is too much for what we got out of it.  It's doubtful we'll return.
author: Alex P.

description: The area is small but it's worth the squeeze. Very delicious food and attentive wait staff.
author: Camille R.

description: This restaurant has become my new favorite in San Francisco. The food is excellent, and the service is also top called me. I highly recommend the calamari as an appetizer, the shaved espresso ice for dessert, and any pasta dish on the menu.  The wine list is wonderful, and I suggest asking for a recommendation from the waiter for non-American wines.
author: Stephen H.

description:
This is a really cute Italian restaurant tucked into a corner slightly off the beaten path.  It would make for a nice special date place.

The lamb was delicious and so was the day's special which was a cod.

Service was generally very attentive and felt pretty similar to an actual restaurant in Milan.

If I'm looking for authentic Italian, I would come back here.
author: Ankur P.

description: Small lovely neighborhood Italian.  Good service, food and wine.  What else you need ?
author: S H.

description:
Went here for dinner the other night and had a grand time.

Small intimate and cozy location with great staff and in a great area.

Starter:
- Special Beet Salad: YUM! Beets, asparagus, orange, pecorino - delicious

Entrees:
- Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa - homemade pasta with porcini mushrooms and sausage. I didn't actually notice any sausage which actually fine by me because I was more excited about the mushrooms. The sauce was VERY thick so I actually got full after eating about half the dish

- Special of the Night: Grilled Walu with grilled veggies. It was marinated to perfection, slightly lemony but tasty with the addition of herbs. It definitely melted in your mouth.

Dessert:
- Tiramisu with decaf coffee and cappuccino. Tiramisu was very fluffy and rich, perfect addition to the coffee/cappuccino. 

Wouldn't've changed a thing. In addition, the staff was amazing and the ambiance was casual making it a very comfortable, yet very intimate. The staff let us hang out with them wayyy past 10:00pm and was very nice about it. They also let you bring your own wine for a small corkage fee of $18.

Wonderful experience, definitely heading back, even if it's for a glass of wine :)
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description:
We originally were slated to go to a differnt place near Nob Hill but ended up at Ristorante Milano instead.  What a stroke of luck!  The food was fabulous!  The bruchette served prior to the meal was extremely doughy and delicious.  The homemade pasta was the best I've had in a long time.  Anyone that has been to Italy would sense the authenticity of the meal.

The restaurant has a home-like atmosphere yet serves meals fit for a fine dining restaurant, extremely flavorful!  The waitress was very sweet and helpful!  She recommended a wine that paired perfectly with our meal.  The rest of the staff was attentive without being obnoxious or in the way.  We had absolutely no complaints and would gladly return if our voyages ever lead us to Nob Hill in San Francisco again!
author: Jill L.

description:
Decent spread but nothing extraordinary.  My lamb was so heavy it tasted like nothing but oil and smoke and was paired with sides that were almost as heavy.  Wife's seafood pasta was good though.

So cramped, I felt like I was at the table with the Marina douchebag/dude-brah party next to us.  Their conversation gets no stars, but somehow I couldn't ignore the totally cliche bullshit coming from their mouths.  

Service was excellent, food was decent, and my big country ass didn't fit so well in the small space.
author: Jimmy C.

description: If you are looking for an intimate neighborhood italian restaurant this is it! The food was amazing.  Grilled calamari is to die for.  Watermelon salad, Yum! Gnochi and chicken all infused with delicious fresh italian flavor! Our waitress Susanna was awesome too!!
author: Jenn A.

description:
I had a dinner party not too long ago.

There were 6 of us in total.

I decided to bust out the Kitchen Aid with the fresh pasta attachment.

All of my activities and flour bombs going off in the kitchen were pretty impressive.  My guests were in awe of my skills and the way I gently pulled pasta from the Kitchen Aid.  

After about 3 hours of work, 22 pounds of flour, 36 eggs, two bloody noses and zero time spent with my guests, I had made enough pasta to satisfy the hunger of a 3 year old girl.  

Each guest got about a bite.  

Note to self.  Hit up Trader Joe's fresh pasta section next time.

Given my experience, I know what it takes to make fresh pasta, so for that, I give kudos (those were good snack bars, remember?) to the fine staff at Ristorante Milano.  

Grace and I met up with some new friends that shall remain nameless for political and security reasons.  Really?  Ok, a hint, one carries a gun and the other carries a chocolate loaded brownie.

Milano just wasn't up to par.  The chicken liver appetizer was ok, but I come from a clan of people that make this stuff and it's a heavenly experience.

My ravioli had a great filling but the pasta was a little undercooked and oily.  

Grace said her pasta was a bit nutty so I, skeptical, had a bite and let's just say I wasn't allergic to walnuts before, but I might be now.  

The place was super cramped so be prepared to get to know your neighbors.  

I hate giving this place 3 stars because the manager/owner was such a nice man.  I am putting Milano into the category of "middle of the week local dinner spot."    

I am thankful though, that the food wasn't especially good.  Since it wasn't, I limited my intake which left room for those brownies and room for some drinks around the corner which is, in itself, a WHOLE 'nother story.  

Bulletproof.
author: Archie R.

description:
Tucked inside of Nob Hill, this neighborhood Italian restaurant is a cozy spot for a dinner out.

Visited for my sister's birthday, and I have to say it was a bit cramped for a party of 5. While the logistics worked, having a bit more space would have been nice.

The menu was a direct reflection of a long, flavorful life of the chef, and it was a pleasure to dive into. I ended up having the linguine with shellfish, which was ok, but not outstanding. 

The gnocchi was flavorful, seasoned well, and comforting, but as the scene goes in San Francisco, it rests with tough competition.

Overall, I think this is a great place for a mid week resting stop, but spare it for a special event.
author: Mike K.

description:
I'm somewhat of a snob when it comes to Italian food (I make really good Italian food at home), so when I entered Ristorante Milano, thoughts such as "It's gonna suck" or "It's gonna be a total rip-off" ran through my head. But I have to say I'm pleasantly surprised. The Tonnarelli Alla Capricciosa, a homemade pasta in light cream sauce with porcini mushrooms and Italian sausage, was delicious. It had just the right amount of light cream without making you feel like you had to run a mile to burn it off.

The dessert, a sort of a chocolate souffle, was a little disappointing as I thought there was just too much fudge. But all in all, the experience was great -- the service, too, was impeccable.
author: Trish C.

description:
This is one of those spots that fits ever so snugly into the "intimate neighborhood restaurant" space. Well-executed Italian standards turned out in a cozy warmly lit room, accompanied by a thoughtful wine list and served up with genuine Italian hospitality.

There are no huge surprises here, just comforting reliability for those evenings when you want good Italian food in a friendly, semi-upscale setting. We shared an appetizer of beef carpaccio, thoroughly enjoyed our pasta entrees of butternut squash ravioli in a rich browned butter & sage sauce, and fabulously, feathery gorgonzola gnocchi with a drizzle of marinara. Two glasses of a pleasant Sangiovese paired well with the food. Dessert was a light affair of pear and apricot sorbetto. Alas, the raspberry flavor was already gone (boo-hoo berry) but it still finished off a delicious meal with just the right amount of sweetness. 

Of course, I'd rather be on a flight to Italy for the real deal, but it's nice to know a small slice of La Dolce Vita is just a few short blocks away.
author: wendella a.

description:
Charming!
Great location but parking sucks.
I took my FF ( female friend ) there for her birthday.
( female friend means more than GF: according to myself )
The waiter was very easy-going, professional and funny.
He remembered her birthday " tiramisu" with a little candle on it.
It was a very romantic night.
But, 
there was a couple sitting right behind us and we could hear that their conversation and we could tell that  they just met. 
1st time daters!

I was all ears. so was my FF.

They were both about late 40s blond hair and the guy was a dick, arrogant son of a B, telling her that he has 3 hotels and 6 cars and asking her to go to his room later.
And the skanky lady was saying her husband went to a business trip for a week!
I couldn't believe what we were hearing.
Well,
They took-off before even finish their food. 
Of course, 
great Italian food and all.
It is about  food and people.
It is about Cincinnati bow tie.
It is about connection!
author: Nobu K.

description:
Great restaurant and great atmosphere. I had the Fettucine alla Puttanesca and the olives accompanied with the housemade Fettucine noodles were amazing. 

The servers were amazing and very attentive in terms of what I needed (water needing to be filled, extra bread, extra cheese) 

Overall a great experience and great food.
author: THOMAS T.

description:
The pretty, skinny waitress smiled way too much at Boyfriend while serving dinner.  I hate her.  As for the food:

I didn't like the radicchio salad.  I didn't perceive any orange flavor in the dressing, and I felt that there was no counterpoint to the bitterness of the greens and Gorgonzola.

The bread in the Crostini Ai Funghi wasn't rigid enough to hold up to the mushrooms, so you had to eat it with a fork.  I really don't like the Gorgonzola this restaurant uses.  It's very acrid.  But I loved the generous amount of mushrooms.

Boyfriend had the seafood over polenta with fish stock, on special.  The scallops were large and clean-tasting, and we both liked the flavor a lot.

I had the Linguine Ai Frutti Di Mare.  The homemade pasta was unique with a rustic, uneven thickness.  I really liked it.  The clams and mussels were nice and fresh.  I will definitely get this again.

This dinner was the first time I've gotten through an entire meal on a single basket of bread (mediocre foccacia).  That was pretty cool.  What wasn't cool was them running out of panna cotta, something I'd been seriously craving.  I bet the waitress with holding back.  Bitch.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Although I enjoyed my dinner, I found that it was quite overpriced for what I received on my plate and in my glass.  Had the food been off the wall stunning, I wouldn't have minded the 100+ bill for a dinner for two with only 1 glass of wine pp, but that wasn't the case.  Perhaps I'm spoiled from being an east coast kid... 
I admit, the service was very attentive, actually, almost too attentive - the waiters seemed to have time to spare (its a small restaurant) so they just kinda ogled the crowd, which bugged me out just a little.  Ah well, what can you do?
author: Karen K.

description:
We came here for our little "cenone di natale" while visiting the City during Christmas. They had a special menu - mostly items from main menu narrowed down. 

Started with a couple ample-sized salads. The beet salad was delicious. Main courses were the house made pappardelle with cinghiale (wild boar, for those not in the know) and the tonnarelli pasta, which I found to be way too heavy with the cream sauce they used. 

Dessert was house made sorbetto. First time I tried cantaloupe sorbetto. It was nice and light.  A good finish to a filling meal.

The service was good, knowledgeable enough, and timing was done well with our plates. Only drawback is the cramped size of the space. Our little two-top was right over the bathroom door and then we had a table next to us with about six inches of space between and you couldn't help but hear all of their conversation. All in all a good spot for some nice Italian fare in a cute nice neighborhood.
author: Slim S.

description: I absolutely loved the food here. I have been to many "authentic" Italian restaurants, but none compare to this place. You can taste how fresh the ingredients are and that all the food is homemade. Seasonal produce was used in a quite innovative way the last time I ate here with strawberries and peaches in a salad. I tried three desserts (yes, three) and I can't even describe how tasty those were. One was made from whipped egg yolks and fresh fruit. Never had it before but it's now a favorite. The owners seem like really nice people and the smaller interior makes for an intimate feel. I'm not sure what someone said before about there being fake plants...this place is far classier than that.
author: Kalila S.

description: This is one of your classic Russian Hill trattorias.  It's intimate and charming, romantic enough for a great date; however, the layout is a bit congested. I was quite fond of the shabby 80s-esque canvas awning sign over the sidewalk.  The food is excellent: we started with a very nice mozzarella con peperoni with a grilled polenta.  The pillows of mozzarella were fresh and...pillowy.  Our main courses consisted of a grigliata mista with sausage, chicken breast and lamb as well as a very flavorful chicken saltimbocca.  For dessert we had the velvetty tiramisu, which was luxurious.  Very good service completes an overall pleasant and satisfying dining venture.
author: Rick H.

description:
This is the best Italian food I've had in San Francisco. If you're like me and avoid the Boyardee gauntlet on Columbus Ave., walk over the hill to this place.

I had the Fettucine alla Ghiotta and it was incredible. The lasagne's reputation preceded it so we got that too -- awesome. Conversation slowed to a crawl... all concentration on the food. The most impressive feat was making grilled calamari taste meaty and mild, rather than the rubber-fish flavor you get almost everywhere.

The waiter (I think he used to work at Liberty Cafe?) was helpful; wine selection was good; food came out on time; dessert menu was great (though we passed); wine menu was better; great ambience. Good for dates or semi-fancy small-group occasions.
author: andy d.

description: Not sure why Mike C. had so much trouble with this place, we had a 7:45 reservation got there early and they seated us at 7:30. Overall service was excellent and the staff was friendly. Food was good, I tried the mixed grill and everything was nicely cooked and tasty. The restaurant is tight so tables are somewhat cramped (ours was an almost too tight squeeze). I'd really like to give this place 3 and 1/2 stars, but since I can't I rounded up.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Photos uploaded.

I am very picky about Italian food.  More specifically, I am really particular about my pasta.  

When in search of good pasta dishes, I don't care about how authentic it is, and whether or not it's available in some corner of Italy, or not.  What I do care about is that it MUST taste good -- not be overpowered by whatever choice of sauce, and most importantly, the noodles must be of great texture, and perfectly cooked.  

Having heard of Ristorante Milano for awhile now, I've even heard someone describe it as a piece of Italy being available in San Francisco.  Needless to say, I had high hopes as I reserved this restaurant for a party of four for dinner.

Another outing with Archie, and this time, we were meeting up with Jacqueline and Andrew for dinner.  We all came hungry, and ordered a lot of food.
Off the top of my head, we had the following:

- Prosciutto with Cheese:  good
- Chicken Liver Dish:  excellent
- Burrata Cheese w/ Tomatoes:  good
- Fried Anchovies or was it Sardines?:  decent
- Bigfin Tuna for Andrew:  didn't try it but it was raw, which was unexpected
- Gnocchi for Jacqueline:  tried it, it was alright, but I am admittedly not a big fan of gnocchi
- Ravioli for Archie:  good pasta, I didn't like the butternut squash filling, altogether too heavy and it looked oily
- My pasta - -can't remember the name but the thick noodles were homemade and perfect cooked - - the sauce was seriously ODD.... like drenched in walnuts.  Overbearing, but A+ for the noodles.

Archie brought two fabulous bottles of wine for us to share, as usual.  

Thanks to Jacqueline, who brought her amazing brownies, we had no need for dessert.  Y'all should try it, great stuff, and readily available here: http://www.jacquelinesgoodies.blogspot.com/ (Yes, that is a plug, what of it?)  Seriously - they were moist and delicious - and while I am not big on sweets, I had to help myself to one anyway.

The place is small, packed and loud.  It is quite reminiscent of a small Italian restaurant - - service was pretty decent, and all in all, I liked the food just fine, but was really quite taken aback by the walnut taste in the otherwise great pasta.  It was entirely too much - and furthermore, there was NO mention of this walnut at all on the menu.  I have a small pet peeve - - and it's small tables.  I mean, it's one thing at a coffeeshop, but at a restaurant that will be bringing out four plates - - I feel like it's rude to give us a small table on which we cannot fit four plates at a time.  The entire mood of a meal is already enlivened when you present dinner at a HUGE table, like it says, "Welcome, eat to your heart's content, you can fit it all on our tables."  The neighborhood has difficult parking -  but there are some cool, local spots nearby, like Cafe Meuse, where Archie and I hung out afterwards.  

All in all, while I enjoyed dinner here, Ristorante Milano missed the mark, and doesn't quite make its way to any list of mine.  I've had much better Italian food at Fino, or other SF places.  

It's not actually perfect for a date, and it's definitely not great for large groups.  It's not a Happy Hour spot, and while the food was overall decent - - I can't say that I thought it was any more deserving than 3-3.5 stars.

The night was terrific in that I was amongst great company, and really enjoyed myself.  I wish I had picked a better restaurant, but oh well.  I did make all my usual disclaimers, "I've never been here, do not blame me for the food, I am hoping it's good too, but I dunno!!!!"  

Thanks, Archie, for dinner - and Jacqueline and Andrew, for coming all the way up to the city just to eat with us!  Now to think of it, Archie - you drove quite a distance also - so thank you for that, too!  

(Funny, I was the only one who was local ... and also the only one who was late.  Oh, the shame!)
author: Grace K.

description:
The homemade pastas at Ristorante Milano take me back to my pack-backing trip to Italy.  Irene S. and I were being followed all over Florenece one day by two gross men, and we quickly ducked into a restaurant that ended up having the most amazing pasta.  We ate there days and many meals in a row, and I think I can do that with the pastas here as well.  Everything we ordered last night from the lasagna, to basic fettuccine milanese, to the fettuccine alla ghiotta and the pasta with shellfish was excellent.  The only disappointing dish was the beef carpaccio.

I agree that tables can be a bit tight.  Also, check out the tiny bathroom...you could wash your hands while you're on the toilet!
author: Carol C.

description:
Nice little place! Friendly staff, good food...maybe a bit noisy, but I'll just chalk that up to atmosphere. Of I can't say I was surprised, because I picked it as had 141 reviews on here with a 4.5 star rating. Oh, my fellow Yelpers. Being all smart and stuff.

When we got there we were seated at our table between a couple and a woman and her mother. We are handed the menus, and as we were deciding the host was telling the couple next to us the specials in his Italian accent. As the place is small, he chose to stand between our two tables, which was slightly weird because his rear end was dangerously close to my head. (Did I mention the place was a bit small?) But I really found that more silly than annoying.

Then the man finished giving the couple the specials and told us he'd be right back for us. And then just a few seconds later a waitress--also sporting and accent--came over and asked us if we were ready to order. We were, but the man tried to say something to her (either we weren't ready, or he wasn't ready, or whatever).

But we were ready, so we ordered.

I ordered the Saltimboco di Pollo (no, neither my memory nor Italian is that good -- I had to look it up on their web site.) Basically: chicken, cheese, prosciutto. YUM.

Then I realized perhaps there was a reason the gentleman wasn't ready for the waitress to take our order. Turns out the folks sitting on either side of us hadn't ordered. In fact, we finished our entrees when they were just getting theirs. I mean, I can't complain about bad service here... but is it  possible our service was *too* good?

As we waited for our food, we noshed on the focaccia bread. Major points for the restaurant for only pouring olive oil to dip the bread in. I mean, seriously, I can't stand vinegar mixed in my olive oil. Here it wasn't even an option (well, maybe we could have asked for it, so if that's your thing, don't despair). Just a little dish of olive oil. Mmmm.

I think my one complaint was that I was a little off put by the Coke can on our table. My friend wanted a Coke. Nothing wrong with that. And I certainly didn't expect the restaurant to have a soda fountain in the back. But I just found it odd--and almost crass, in some weird way--that in this nice little restaurant with tiny tables and white tableclothes, that a Coke can would be sitting in the middle of a table. Next time, maybe pour it in the kitchen and bring it out. Or get those cute glass bottles. 

Oh! And the bathroom is adorably tiny. Which I discovered because my water glass was never empty for more than a few seconds.
author: Tara B.

description:
Some of the best Ravioli I have ever had. Much better than in a lot of touristy restaurants in Florence or Rome. Their lasagna wasn't bad at all, neither. Great small restaurant atmosphere with a very friendly and service oriented staff.

Only complaint was dessert. We had the profiteroles and they were very dry, even with chocolate sauce. But then again, I think that's the way profiteroles are supposed to be ;)
author: Erik Z.

description:
Growing up with a 3rd generation half-Italian father who did all of the cooking in my household as I grew up, the gauge by which I judge Italian food is by no means that of a connoisseur.  And also, because of this distinctive relationship to italian food, my judgement is probably biased.

However, the food here was excellent.  Truth be told, I didn't have to pay for it ... which may have made it better, but I did have the full-on experience including antipasti, entree, wine, and dessert.  And to make it even better we had a waitress from Italy, who was also really hot.  It didn't hurt the experience.

There were many great things about the meal, but my favorite dish was my entree, which was a saffron chicken risotto with zucchini.  I've never seen saffron risotto offered at a restaurant (it's always that mushy *other* risotto which I'm not really a fan of) and thought that my dad was the only one who prepared it that way.  But I was pleasantly wrong as this was absolutely phenomenal.  The rice was the perfectly aldente, the chicken was tender and tasty, and the zucchini was added at a point where it was warm but still crispy.

Mmm.

One thing that would have made my dining experience over the top, would have been to review the menu before hearing the specials.  They have many regular specials that are all noted in their menu, and had I known that, it would have been easier to follow.

Otherwise, if you have some cash to drop, this is a great place to eat.
author: Becca B.

description:
Okay, look. It's really good Italian food in an intimate and romantic restaurant. Really, what is not to like? Is there anything better in life? Is there??

I might have had the best ice cream in my entire life there. Maybe it was gelato, I don't know, I don't care. I'm telling you, it was so delectable, fresh, creamy, and light. 

Nothing was wrong. Everything was right!!
author: Sahra H.

description:
I came here for dinner last night with my boyfriend and his dad. We had spent the day in Napa and were just looking for a local place to finish off the day. I made a reservation online at 7:40pm for 8:30pm so that was awesome, and when we got there we were seated within a few minutes even though the place was full. Minus one star because the place was basically a fire hazard with way too many tables and people waiting by the door to be seated (the whole time we were there). Basically no room to back up your chair because someone was seated right behind you.

Aside from the obvious lack of space, the food was excellent and the bottle of wine we got was some of the best I've ever had. Friendly servers and homemade pasta was a huge plus. We did have to request an olive oil refill 3 times, but maybe that just makes us fatties. Slightly overpriced but I guess that's what you can expect in the city. Overall a nice, convenient place to end a busy day.
author: Natalie H.

description:
My friends know I'm the obnoxious foodie type.  The kind who wants every meal to be delicious and would rather not eat than eat bad, or even mediocre, food.

Last night I had a non-foodie moment (what can I blame for this: exhaustion, laziness?).   I just wanted to have some regular, basic Italian comfort food within walking distance from my place.  I didn't care to hear about the provenance of the olive oil or that the porcini mushrooms were overnighted from Italy.  In retrospect...  maybe I should have cared.

See, I had been to Ristorante Milano before, about a year ago.  I remember laughing at the horribly dated, cheapie decor and tacky low-budget place settings.  But I remember the food being unexpectedly good.  Sadly this is no longer the case.

Are my standards too high?  Is it ok to serve stale foccacia, flavorless olive oil (surely some low-quality blend), an equally flavorless salad of amaturely sliced fennel, weedy arugula, olives, and burrata that desperately needed a squirt of lemon and better olive oil and good salt (salt on the table being the awful diner kind... I'm seriously considering toting my own box of fleur de sel with me to restaurants to avoid this sad fate)?  It is also all right to pass off a truly underseasoned, soggy mess of overcooked noodles as lasagne?  Where was the rich bechamel?  The deep flavors of long-simmered meat?  All I tasted were rudimentary tomato flavors scented with eau de tin can. 

At least the tiramisu marginally redeemed the experience.  It was excellent.  

Food this bleak would normally make me angry.  But I'm not.  Maybe because the company was good and I was too relaxed to care.  Or maybe I've reached this zen-like mental state where I accept that not every restaurant can be great.  

Well.  Maybe not every restaurant is great... but I think I'll stick with patronizing the great ones.
author: Melissa B.

description:
this is your neighborhood friendly, affordable and good restaurant.  Parking sucks, but the food was great.  I ordered the gnocci and I thought it was delicious.  the chicken was a bit dry.  I think I would stick to their pasta dishes for it seems like it does taste better.  

the place is a bit small so if you did not make reservations, you will most likely be waiting.  will be back to try some of their other pasta dishes.
author: AhLin C.

description:
It was a full house on a Saturday night!  We enjoyed the crowded but romantic setting, professional and friendly service, and large selection of wines.  They have a wonderfully fresh gnocchi in a creamy gorgonzola sauce.  
Some of the tables are rather close together, but there is a small room in the front and a raised loft-like space in the back that appeared to offer a little more distance between tables. 
Buon Appetito!
author: Heather M.

description:
We met friends for dinner at Milano and although the food was exquisite, the entire experience was ruined by our waitress and the attitude of the manager on duty, Albo/Aldo(?).  Our waitress was a Spanish/Hispanic brunette woman on the shorter side (wish I knew her name) who was extremely rude to us while ordering and during the meal.  

At one point, one of our friends asked, "Is the fish a special?" and she said "Yeah...I just told you that!"  Needless to say, we overlooked the 3 times she snapped at us/was rude because the food and ambiance were nice and everyone has a tough day once in awhile.  However, after ordering our after-dinner coffee we were sitting and talking when the waitress came up and said "Excuse me, but folks are waiting for your table so please finish up your conversation as we need the table now."

ARE YOU F-ING KIDDING ME?  We just dropped $250 for dinner and we weren't lingering--we were still drinking our coffee!  That was the final straw...I walked down and asked for the manager.  He identified himself as Albo/Aldo.  I explained what had happened and he said "Can you tell me exactly how she was rude?"  I replied, "you mean outside of trying to kick us out of your restaurant after we spent $250?"  He offered to talk with her later, but wasn't in any rush to assuage our bitterness.  

We decided we had better leave (after all, they apparently needed the table despite not seeing anyone waiting at the door).  On the way out the door, Albo/Aldo tried to explain that sometimes they get backed up and they just wanted us to know that there were folks waiting, but they weren't trying to kick us out.  Again, ARE YOU F-ING KIDDING ME?  "We wanted you to know that folks aren't waiting, but we aren't kicking you out"?????

Needless to say, despite fantastic food I would avoid this place.  They overcharge a bit (which we were willing to overlook) and the service and management are really, really awful!
author: Collin H.

description: Went here on a Wednesday night with friends. I think they specifically picked it out because of the 1/2 off bottles of wine. I had a seafood fettuccini which was excellent. My friends liked their pasta too. We loved the wine and the fact that we paid $30 each and left with full bellies AND had two bottles of wine! We had to wait a few minutes for our table, but they gave us each a glass of champagne for our wait which made me love them even more. I would definitely go back...especially on a Wednesday!
author: Sabrina P.

description:
This is a rather belated review but I wanted to make sure I say how much I enjoyed this place. It was fabulous when I lived walking distance from here. It felt like the neighborhood Italian joint, very homey and welcoming. The people there were the absolute nicest as well (including some flirting on the side but hey, they're Italian). 

We kept coming back and bringing different groups of friends and family who all enjoyed it too. The gnocchi is really great here and the burrata's delish too. Don't expect innovative cuisine here but they deliver well on the basics. 

Parking around the area can also be challenging so find other modes of transportation here if you can.
author: Sharon K.

description:
Imagine we're in American idol for a second:

Randy says, "Baby, that was a nice performance, but I expected more!"
Paula says, "You really had nice vocals, but you picked the wrong song."
Simon says, "You were awful and your dress was horrible."

Bathroom report:
This bathroom is small, if you're a big dude like myself you'll feel like your being squeezed into a straight jacket.

Honestly, I don't even remember the food I order, so I must not have been that impressed.
author: Michael S.

description:
Aldo, the owner is a great proprietor.  I love eating here and I love giving him my money and I love to come back.
The waiters, Reno and Maurio, are cool too.  The people who work here are all really nice and that adds to the overall dining experience.  

I love cappelini al pomodoro.  The one they make here is in first place now.

Tiramisu is made, not bought.  Its very good.  I don't care for Tiramisu but I can eat the whole serving here.  

They let you take out too!  They are also very accomodating.  They halve my pasta orders all the time with a smile.  
They make things for me not on the menu all the time.  I'm vegetarian and I get bored of no selection.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Milano is a sentimental favorite of mine and ranks as one of the most enjoyable dining experiences in the city.  Charming and intimate, this romantic little neighborhood Italian restaurant offers excellent service where the Italian servers treat you as though you are a guest in their home.  The dim lighting and soft din makes this an excellent place for a date where you can enjoy both great cuisine and conversation.

Their pasta dishes offer bold, delectable flavors with the standout being their gnocchi, which is so light it almost floats off the plate (a far cry from the dense potato depth charges many Italian eateries serve).  My last visit I enjoyed their special, a seafood polenta, which if regularly available might pull me away from old favorites like the Gnocchi con Salsa Aurora and the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa.

Cap off any meal with their Tiramisu and I can assure you that you (and your date) will leave happy.
author: Drew W.

description:
Ristorante Milano was really cute. It was homey. It was where you can go either on a date, or on a mellow night with your girls. 

You should most definitely cab it there. Even in a Smart car, parking was a pain. And, to be honest though, I didn't mind the few blocks we walked. The neighborhood is really cute and calm. And you can smell winter in the air. Crisp, the fire's are going in people's homes, holiday parties were bustling within happy homes. 

We started with a mushroom bruschette. I was trying to be polite by using a fork and knife...had to put it down and just dig into it. No time for cute...time for food! 

Good selection of Italian and Californian wines. I had the Nero D'Avola, inexpensive and delicious. 

My dinner company had a seafood stew. I wasn't impressed.  

For dinner, I had the spinach ravioli's with a red sauce. It was good. It wasn't as good as I hoped. Something was missing...a little more flavor maybe? Not sure. 

I should have gone with the lasagna. The table next to us ordered it, and it looked yummy. It was all gone to...leads for me to conclude that it must have been good.
author: Marivel M.

description:
Love Love Love!

This is one of my favorite places in the city.  The staff is always friendly and knowledgeable.  The food is ALWAYS delicious.  The specials are always changing, and always mouthwatering.  The wine list is great.  The portions are large, but not gargantuan.    I really can't say enough great things about this place.

And if you call in, you can get take out and eat the amazing pasta in your PJ's on your couch watching reality TV.  Or so I've heard.
author: Julie E.

description: To be honest, I really don't see what the hype is. I found their service to be good, but I didn't find my food to be all that excellent. Their menu was tiny and I'm sort of a picky eater so I just asked for penne and marinara. Can't screw that up, right? Well, wrong, because my pasta was so oily. How can pasta be oily? I don't really know, but it was. And I'm pretty sure it was coming out of my pores an hour later. Yuck. Won't return.
author: M B.

description:
The most perfect, quaint, Italian restaurant. My boyfriend took me to dinner here, and we had one of the best restaurant experiences I have ever had. IN MY LIFE. And I know I am only 23, but when your mother is a chef, you go to A LOT of restaurants. 

Lets start with the service- we had the nicest server- he was a total character and his recommendations were spot on. His surfer dude combined with total foodie personality really showed through and my boyfriend told me had a man crush on him (strangely, I love that my boyfriend admitted this tidbit. what a real man!).

Anyways, the food was spectacular. We started with the burrata served over arugula and fennel. The portion was large and the burrata was perfectly doughy and so, so fresh. For entrees, we ordered the meat lasagna and a pasta dish with porcini mushrooms and sausage. Be prepared for a very rich, flavorful, homemade meal.

This was the best pasta I have had in the city. The venue is cozy and quaint- a perfect date place. Their wine list is impressive, as they serve both California wines and Italian wines. 

I really can't say enough wonderful things about Restaurant Milano. I can't wait to come back.
author: Laura D.

description:
Okay, the food is awesome, the wine list comprehensive, the gnocchi divine ... but let's talk about the ambiance and the service!!  The staff here are smooth operators, very smooth.  When I called in our reservation, a warm "buona sera" were the first words to greet me.  Then when we rolled up, a lovely window-side table awaited us.  

The ambiance is warm, friendly and very very cozy. From the precise attention to our every need to the Maitre'D coming around to check in on us, to even the wine-bringer-girl complimenting my date's stylish tuque and my shirt.  very smooth.  Overall, they know how to put their guests right at ease so that they can better enjoy the sumptuous fare. 5 stars.
author: I. O.

description: Excellent pasta.  Try home made pasta with porcini mushroom and Italian sausage. Grill octopus.
author: Leo O.

description: Seated promptly.  Great service.  Reasonable prices and delicious food.  The gnocchi was excellent as well as the fresh bread.
author: Christopher C.

description:
I was very happy with the food here, but slightly disappointed since I had read rave reviews here and elsewhere and my experience fell a bit short.

The gnocchi was delicious; very soft and melt-in-your mouth ... the fish was average. Definitely order pasta here, not anything else. The pasta is homemade and very good. The linguine my companion had was very good, with zucchini and mint in it, a nice zesty combo.
author: Brian B.

description:
Pretty good food. I was very satisfied with my linguine con cozze, which was a tomato and parsley sauce with mussels. Very very good. 
My boyfriend had a minestrone that was much lighter in taste, color and quantity of vegetables than any minestrones I have ever had, but it was still pretty good. 
For dessert, I had the sorbets (mango, strawberry and pear). The pear was probably the best-- not that the mango and strawberry weren't; they were just more ordinary-tasting. 

Loved the atmosphere more than anything. Cute little place, fancy-enough and yet not overwhelmingly formal. 
I would go back.
author: Saori E.

description:
I give this place a solid 4 star rating (and my boyfriend also agrees). We had a nice dining experience here for our Valentine's night. The staff was friendly and attentive. The best dish came early in the meal which was the arugula with burrata cheese. So good!
The broccoli/pea soup, wild boar ragout with papparedelle egg noodles, and meat lasagna were all pretty tasty. I usually like salty dishes - the wild boar ragout was plenty salty for my taste.
author: Iku R.

description:
I don't ever order meat. It's not that I don't like meat. It's just that anything with that kind of protein content fills up my stomach much too quickly, prohibiting me from adequately stuffing my face for the requisite ninety minutes of the oh-so-rare date night. I ordered meat lasagna. It was the single best pasta dish I have had this year, and believe me, I have been a-samplin. We started with the mushroom-gorgonzola bruschetta and the burratta (two stars for having burratta). We also had two delicious bottles of wine. Wonderful staff. Amazing food. Taking my mother back for date night this week.

***called to make reservations for the aforementioned mom date: simply the nicest service EVER. Had another delicious dinner- the only thing that would have made it better would have been a birthday dessert for the fabulous visiting birthday girl! I'm sure they would have done this if they weren't so busy***
author: Katie T.

description:
My wife & I have been going here for nearly 20 years. Several years ago the quality declined, but we're glad we checked it out again last night! Wonderful grilled calamari & white bean app, lamb chops, pinot nero ... just hoping they bring back the zabaione. 
A real neighborhood, locals restaurant. Think we were the youngest folks there. Comforting!
author: Eric W.

description:
Fun authentic Italian place! There was little wait so the owner let us order a bottle of Chianti and we had a great time just sitting outside (it was not a cold night...thank god). The food was great, our server was very personable (and Italian always a plus!) Everything is homemade and I just liked the entire vibe of the place. 
I had the ravioli but next time I will be ordering the gnocchi- I tried my friends and it tasted like little pockets of heaven :)
author: Janae L.

description:
This place has great pizza. 

I went around dinner time on a Saturday night and got the last open table. Ordered a Greek salad and a pizza, and couldn't be happier right now.

In fact, all I can think about is the slice that's sitting in the fridge right now.

If you are hanging out in the Sunset on a Saturday night, you gotta go here for a slice.
author: Andrew M.

description:
1. I was proposed to here.
2. It is my favorite restaurant in all of the City
3. The Gnocchi with Gorgonzola is orgasmic

Enough said...
author: Katey M.

description: This quaint  restaurant offers a great atmosphere and food.  The pasta appears to be house made and extremely delicious.
author: Grant K.

description: I've been here about 5 times now for birthday and anniversary meals, and taken out of town guests. The food is amazing with homemade pastas and very good seafood. It's a very narrow restaurant, so I wouldn't recommend it for groups (I would say 4 people max) - there are extra tables on a loft area above the main dining area, but it's pretty cramped up there too. My visit last Friday was my first in 2-3 years (lots of good eating in SF!) and the service was unfortunately erratic. Friendly waiter and hostess. We got our drinks and food order taken fairly quickly. Appetizers and pasta course came out together - not a big deal; we were hungry and were sharing everything anyway. Plates were cleared quickly. But then, a good long wait before our entrees...felt like 20-30 minutes? I don't remember anyone checking up on us...granted it was a Friday evening and the restaurant started to get busier and busier. Entrees were very good when they arrived, but again, no check-in w/us during the meal. Soon we were looking for our waiter to ask for the check, and he was very busy w/the other diners. I managed to get his attention and ask for the check, but he never returned to our table after that, obviously forgetting about us. I flagged down the hostess who eventually brought me the bill (but had to get our food ticket from the waiter to ring it up anyway). That whole paying process took another 20 minutes which was frustrating and reflected in my tip. I hope this was a one-time mishap - as I said earlier, the food is amazing and I've had no other problems w/the service in the past, hence I'm only removing one-star.
author: Barbara K.

description: Pretty pricey for somewhat good, but average-ish Italian food (I think it's hard for a restaurant to mess up Italian food).  I am basing this review on the 4 dishes we ordered.  Parking is a nightmare.  The wait area is so small and crowded (on a Saturday night, 8:30PM, even with a reservation).  Their bathroom is the smallest bathroom I've ever seen.  I doubt I'll be going back.
author: A T.

description:
This place was amazing. My boyfriend and I went here for our four year anniversary. Definitely not cheap but the food was great, our waiter was both charming and helpful, and we even received a surprise off-the-menu dessert (zabaione, which was wonderful). We started with the buffalo mozzarella special served with arugula and fennel. The mozz. had a meaty, smokey taste... but strangely really great. The arugula and fennel had a great vin and this was for sure the right dish to start with. The bf got the polenta with peppers, onions, and homemade sausage for his entree and loved it the whole way through. I ordered linguini with fresh tomatoes, mussels, and thin rectangles of a hard cheese (i think romano, but i don't remember!). Also very delicious. The vibe was, as all other yelpers mention, cozy, which the bf and I found to be just the right degree of romance.

I'll definitely be going back!
author: mern b.

description:
Quite simply, my favorite neighborhood restaurant and squarely within my "top 5 in SF".

I've been here probably a half dozen times in the past year and at the end of each visit I always think "why don't I come here more?".  Surely a sign of a great place.  

I've never had a bad dish here and there are many standouts.
The rare tuna appetizer with meyer lemon infused oil changed my life and is not to be missed.  The grilled calamari and the gnocchi are also great to share with a group--both are simple, flavorful, and delicious.
I love that this place often has many specials--charmingly described by Aldo, the owner.  I often go the specials route, particularly if they include seafood, but the Griglia Mista is a huge crowd pleaser.

I love taking out-of-town guests here for a memorable dining experience--it's always a hit.

I'm also mildly besotted with the Argentinian waitress who I've been lucky enough to have as my server on almost every visit.  She's like a hotter Ana Ortiz and she's a huge part of Milano's charm.
author: Auburn D.

description:
I have been going to this restaurant for the last 6 years -- absolutely LOVE  them!

Their menu is always (basically) the same, but this is part of their charm:  rustic, house made pasta, simple and amazing sauces, beautiful appetizers and waiters with an Italian accent.

My mother makes this a 'must visit' when she comes to SF.  I adore everything on their menu. 

I have never had a complaint and have always been delighted!

I dream of their creamy Alfredo and house made sausage sauce over fettuccine.  Yum!

Bring me their carpaccio!  Bring me their calamari!  Bring me any of their chicken dishes!  Bring be anything on their menu!!

I LOVE RISTORANTE MILANO!!
author: Sarah T.

description: This is a tiny restaurant where you feel kind of squished into the seating, unless you get lucky and get a seat beside the front window. I can't say much about the serving style...very basic. The veal at dinner was brightened with the addition of capers and quite lovely, just as I anticipated.  However, until they upgrade their bread (too soft and flavorless) I would suggest you save the calories.  This restaurant has the potential to become a notable spot, but for now, I think it is a little pricey for a place that is still evolving.
author: Lynn S.

description: I haven't been to Milano in a few years due to the food being so salty, but I went there Saturday night for dinner and this place redeemed itself. The antipasto plate and the bruschetta were delicious. I enjoyed the fritatta and the fresh mozzarella on the bruschetta was a hit. I had the pasta with the light cream sauce with sausage and mushrooms and enjoyed it tremendously. The wine our server recommended was so good that we had to get a second bottle. If I'm craving fresh pasta, I'll definitely return to Milano.
author: Kevin C.

description:
One of my favorite little restaurants in the city.  My husband brought me here for our very first Valentine's Day together (way back when).  Since then we've been back several times and every visit has been amazing.  The most important thing is that the food here is consistently good - no matter what you order.

We treated my mom and grandma here for Mother's Day.  We all shared the grilled calamari with cannelloni beans and the bruschetta with mushrooms and Gorgonzola cheese.  So good.  As my husband says, he could have made an entire meal from the bruschetta dish alone.  I agree, but then we wouldn't have enjoyed these next dishes...  

Grilled chicken with a light balsamic sauce, steak with white wine polenta and mushrooms, chicken saltimbocca, lasagna, and the best dish of the evening - pasta with porcini mushroom and Italian sausage.  Everything was very good, but that pasta was just fantastic.  I have to go back very soon just to get a plate of that pasta for myself.  

Amazingly, we still had room for dessert.  We shared the tiramisu, persimmon sorbet, and the poached pear.  Divine!

The place is small, so if you have a large party, it's going to be tight.  In terms of service, our waiter was fantastic.  I can't say enough about him.  So personable and just all out friendly (not to mention cute with an Italian accent.  HELLO!)  The owner or manager ( I don't know who he was) - I don't think he liked it when my dad commented that our table for 5 was so small.  We basically got two small tables pushed together and then an extra chair on the side.  The "owner" went around to check on every table through the evening and ask how they were.  Every table except ours.  Whatever.  Lucky for him the food and our waiter were so good.
author: Denise M.

description:
Just amazing. Yes, I am giving Ristorante Milano the dynamic five stars that I seldom give out to restaurants. But there is nothing bad that I found about the restaurant to be honest. 

When my party arrived, we were offered numerous tables in the back, middle, and front of the restaurant--we decided to stay up front. And although the menu was already filled with an amazing assortment of appetizers and entrees, they had numerous specials that were quite delicious. I had the Tonnarelli Alla Capricciosa, which everyone at my table finished off. My lover had the pasta special which was lamb and really good. The bro had Ahi carpaccio which was really tasty too. For appetizers, I would recommend the Speck E Formaggi because they have fresh prosciutto and the best soft and hard cheeses I have yet tasted. 

And now the finale--dessert! I was a bit disappointed because I had the impression that they had Zabaione Caldo (warm custard whipped to order with Marsala wine and vanilla), but it wasn't on the menu. Bummer. The boys order Tiramisu and I questioned the server about the Zabaione and they made it specially for me!!! Yay! 

No restaurants can ever go wrong with great service, great food and also making their customers feel special! Magnifico!
author: Maureen B.

description: Outstanding litle italian place.  Tiny, hole in the wall, great service.  Aldo the owner is keen with the wine suggestions.  The gnocchi was superlative.
author: Nick H.

description:
We found this amazing little restaraunt through yelp. 

WOW. We made reservations. Pretty early because we were taking my boyfriends mom out after we saw a Christmas Carol in the afternoon. We got there right as they were opening, they were very welcoming and friendly. The restaraunt itself is really cute. All of the staff is really nice-real family style! Definitely authentic Italian, I loved our servers accent. Anywhoo, good Italian beer, good wine selection. Good bread.
I ordered the gnochi, in a DELICIOUS cream sauce! They're like little pillows of heaven. 
Definitely the best gnochi ever!
Boyfriend ordered the lasagna. AMAZING. They make everything from scratch, they're own noodles, everyhing. Best lasagna ever! Which hurt his moms feeling a little, until she tried it. 
Moms got the Ricotta. She thought it wasamazing. And loved that's it came out steaming hot.


We all really lived the service. We could tell
most of the customers came in all the time and the place was quickly filled! Best Italian in SF!
author: Aubrey M.

description:
Busy on a Saturday night.  A nice neighborhood restaurant - don't come across town to eat here.  

The waitress was somewhat difficult.  We asked to split a dish and to substitute sauces on a pasta dish and she got fidgety and nervous.  

Gnocchi were pretty good, light and fluffy.  The grilled chicken was very basic, nothing special.  I'd say stick with the pasta dishes.

I thought the waitress was going to flip when we split the bill on more than one credit card but she managed to avoid having a heart attack while we were there.

The woman who sat behind me was being very piggy with space... tables are close together.  I hate it when people hog space in tight quarters.
author: Aaron T.

description:
My wife, son, and I ate here on a Tuesday evening.  We were seated in the 4-table upper level of this split level restaurant, which was a blessing and allowed us to enjoy our food.  Other than ourselves, upper level diners included a solo diner, and a young couple.  The lower level, however, was beset by a family with a constantly crying child (whose parents made no move to soothe it) and a table of 8 boisterous men acting like boys.  I mention this only to point out that the staff had the good sense to segregate us -- props to them.  We all agreed that, given a different set of dining companions, it might be nice to sit near the large front windows to watch the street life.

The waiter was attentive and helpful, and suggested a perfect Chianti Classico.  The only missed note was the grilled calamari appetizer, which was probably wonderful when it first came off the grill.  However, it arrived warm and quickly cooled, after which it was not very nice.  Although the meal started poorly, it quickly recovered.  My son had lamb sausage and polenta, my wife had gnocchi in a tomato cream sauce, and I had a lovely ravioli stuffed with sausage and Gorgonzola.  All of our entrees were perfectly prepared -- the sausage and polenta was particularly outstanding.  

The desserts were flawless: tiramisu, poached pear, and chocolate cake with almonds.  Nobody was willing to share, and that's unusual for us.  And telling.

Of particular note was the busboy ("boy" seems an inappropriate appellation for a swarthy man with an earring who looks like a pirate), who scurried around unobtrusively but incredibly efficiently.  He was noticeable only because he was so perfectly diligent.  Everything on the table was just right, always, as it should be.
author: Jim M.

description:
My partner and I enjoyed dinner here for a birthday celebration.  The ambiance is cute, but the place is super small and they cram as many tables and chairs in the dining area as possible.  We had to request a different table b/c I couldn't squeeze into my chair.....mind you I"m not a particularly big girl either.  

The food was good, the gnocchi was delicious and the mushroom bruschetta was amazing!!!!!  We brought our own bottle of wine and that went over well.

The place is so tiny and noisy that I was often distracted by other conversations at the table adjacent to us.  Everything is so close, I felt like I was dining with the other table.

So the long and short of it:  good food, small place, pretty uncomfortable and not so relaxing.  I would not recommend this place for a quiet or romantic meal.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I have wanted to try this place since first moving into the neighborhood, and last night it finally happened. We made a reservation on Opentable.com and were on our merry way once I was home from work. God I love opentable.com. Sorry I digress. 

This place is very very charming. It has a modern flare to it with the art and booths. Not what you would expect in the Nob Hill area, but still quite nice.  I thought the ambiance was deliteful. We sat in the front window, sort of secluded from the rest of the restaurant. We had a lovely, peaceful meal.

I had the ravioli of the night, butternut squash, and my boyfriend had the mushroom and sauage pasta. While the portions looked small upon arrival, we both only ate half of our meals, saving a little room for dessert. We paid roughly $13.50 for our entrees. I have eaten at much more expensive places and easily paid$19.00 for much smaller portion sizes.

They had a decent wine list, a good mix of Italian and American wines.  Which is always nice, that way you can order something yuo recognize if you're not feeling adventurous. They also have an extensive dessert wine list, which includes 2 Muscatos...my absolute favorite!!

On top of great food, we also had great service. The staff was fun and friendly, and from stuffy.

A great local place that I hope to return to time and time again.
author: Aubrey W.

description:
Right or wrong, the quality of a restaurant's bread frequently sets the tone for my enjoyment of a meal (what can I say, I'm a carb-whore - plus, depending on the quality of the company, good bread can keep that serotonin level high until you can drown the pain with alcohol). Fortunately, that was not an issue in this case, but the warm focaccia and olive oil kept me pretty entertained regardless. The staff kept us equally entertained, with the owner pouring our wine and our Italian waiter keeping aforementioned focaccia in sufficient supply to satisfy my descent into gluttony. 

The decor is warm and cozy, but the space is rather small, so unless you can score a large table in the front alcove, or up on the raised area in back, it's probably not best to bring 10 of your closest friends.

We shared the prosciutto and fig appetizer, which comes with some mixed greens and drizzled with balsamic, and is big enough for two people to each have plenty.  The flavors are perfect, and they somehow nail the ripeness of the figs so that they aren't too sweet. I think I just drooled on myself again.

For entrees, I had a butternut squash risotto, and my friend had the gnocchi. Both were great, but the gnocchi was truly melt in your mouth. I think I even managed to forget about the bread by that point....
author: S T.

description:
Parking is a nightmare, but it is worth the hassle, the food is fantastic.

Not a place you would normally drive by since it is buried in a neighborhood, but worth the efforts to find it.

Great place for a date, it has some real charm to it.  We shared everything ordered at our table and I liked everything I tasted.

Definitely recommended.
author: Doug M.

description:
Great little place for real Italian food.  We don't get much in the way of authentic Italian food here in the Denver Boulder area and we appreciative of all the great reviews while visiting SF.  

Ristornate Milano did not let us down.  My wife had the tuna special that was excellent and I had the squash ravioli.  The ravioli's were great but the amount of butter sauce was verging on excessive and could have used a little more sage and a little less butter.
 The real highlight of the meal for me was the sardine appetizer.  Next time I'll just get two plates of sardines!

Service was attentive and although I know it is a great tip ploy - the waiter complimented my wife on her curly hair - made her night!

I found the pricing to be very good for the small restaurant - big city experience.
author: Mark M.

description: We dined here tonight after about a 3 year hiatus.  We were greeted by Raphael, who actually remembered us from our last visit and even recalled the table we sat at.  And we recognized some of the staff, many of whom have been there for years.  Service was outstanding, friendly and attentive.  Food was excellent too - we ordered several different dishes including veal scaloppini, saltimbocca and a special seafood mix of shrimp, scallops, clams & mussels in a red sauce over polenta and all were great.  For dessert, we shared tiramisu and thought it was delicious.  In short, a happy return reminding us that we need to visit this fairly small, local establishment more often.
author: Stephen F.

description: hadn't been here in years, but the homemade pasta is still good.  i had the frutti di mare, and it was generous w/ tons of mussels, clams, prawns, and scallops.  the pasta is so delicious and perfectly cooked.  this is a great neighborhood spot and perfect for a date or dinner w/ friends.
author: Helen T.

description:
Milano is just about as good as it gets when it comes to Italian food in the City. Everything I had during my visit was absolutely delicious, perfectly cooked. and well presented (Antipasto Misto; Crostini ai Funghi; Gnocchi; Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa; Tiramisu; etc.)

The reason I gave Milano a four star instead of five is simple: our table was moved three times by wait staff in order to accommodate another party's size; this whole ordeal got a tad bit annoying after the second time but still didn't distract me and my date from our incredible dinner. 

I'll have to return and try some of the larger plates (we were definitely feeling the pasta that night).

GNOCCHI!
author: Brian J.

description:
Had a birthday dinner here on a Saturday night, party of 8 at 8:30pm.

I should start off by saying that I generally don't like eating out at expensive-y italian restaurants because I feel like I can make tasty italian food at home for a tiny fraction of restaurant prices.

Aldo was very accommodating and our waitress was spunky and awesome.  Some of our party was early and some were late, but they seated me and some other who came early immediately. 

We got some bread as we ordered (ie. after the late-comers finally arrived) and I was starving.  So I ate three slices of the tasty bread (they cut these slices big!)

I ordered the tonnatelli w/ porcini mushrooms, italian sausage in a light cream sauce.p  The tonnatelli itself was nice, but the overall dish was bland.  I couldn't taste the porcini or the italian sausage!  I added salt and parm cheese but it didn't really do too much.  Needless to say I was disappointed.

I tried my friend's gnocchi which was excellent, so I know they definitely have good food.  I just chose the wrong dish....but I don't like restaurants that have good dishes and bad dishes. They should all be good!

The service though, was excellent. Our waitress was very sweet and fun.  We had brought in a cake for dessert so they served it for us ($20 "corkage" fee) and sang to the three birthday girls.

On our way out the girl who made the reservations thanked Aldo for his kindness and he followed us out and thanked us for coming and asked if we had a good meal.  It was really nice to see him so involved on the floor.

So the service was excellent but my dish was just "meh."  Was it worth the $27+ (not including any drinks)?  likely not.  Good service is treat but it can't make up for a bland dish.
author: Naoko M.

description:
What a pleasure. The food was so delicious, the appetizer sardine gratinate, the Tonnarelli alla Capricciosa
